search.query: ("Stress Disorders, Traumatic"[MeSH] OR PTSD[tiab] OR "post-traumatic stress"[tiab] OR "posttraumatic stress"[tiab]) AND ("voxel based morphometry"[tiab] OR VBM[tiab] OR morphometr*[tiab] OR volumetr*[tiab] OR "cortical thickness"[tiab] OR "brain volume"[tiab] OR "grey matter"[tiab] OR "gray matter"[tiab])

abstract.objective: identify studies reporting structural brain alterations associated with PTSD
inclusion_criteria: Peer reviewed MRI studies reporting results among adult humans
Sample- Adult humans. At least one group of individuals with PTSD, must be included the study.
Study must report gray matter structural differences (i.e. voxel based morphometry) associated with PTSD
exclusion_criteria: Non-empirical papers (e.g., reviews, meta-analyses, methods-only, simulations) without original MRI data.
Studies only reporting white matter structural differences

fulltext.objective: identify studies reporting structural brain alterations comparing the following groups: individuals with PTSD, individuals who experienced trauma but were not diagnosed with PTSD, and individuals who did not report experiencing trauma.
inclusion_criteria: Study must measure voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume or concentration using MRI.

Sample- At least one group of individuals with PTSD, and at least one comparison group (either trauma-exposed individuals without PTSD or trauma-unexposed healthy controls) must be included in the study.

Whole-brain evidence- The paper must report at least one whole-brain voxel based morphometry (VBM) result, comparing individuals with PTSD to either trauma-exposed individuals without PTSD or trauma-unexposed healthy controls.
It is acceptable for qualifying whole-brain results to be reported in tables of coordinates, figures, or supplementary materials, as long as they are clearly described in the text.
exclusion_criteria: Trauma or stressful life event studies not measuring PTSD

Studies that do not report coordinate-based results of at least one between group contrast, comparing individuals with PTSD to either trauma-exposed individuals without PTSD or trauma-unexposed healthy controls.
Studies that only report treatment and longitudinal effects
Studies that only region-of-interest (ROI) analyses with no whole-brain results, or only within-group effects, or only null effects, or only other non-voxel-based morphometry methods
Studies that only include non-adult participants (e.g., children, adolescents, elderly)

studies.title: Gray Matter Alterations in Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder, Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder, and Social Anxiety Disorder.
studies.abstract: Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), and social anxiety disorder (SAD) all bear the core symptom of anxiety and are separately classified in the new DSM-5 system. The aim of the present study is to obtain evidence for neuroanatomical difference for these disorders. We applied voxel-based morphometry (VBM) with Diffeomorphic Anatomical Registration Through Exponentiated Lie to compare gray matter volume (GMV) in magnetic resonance images obtained for 30 patients with PTSD, 29 patients with OCD, 20 patients with SAD, and 30 healthy controls. GMV across all four groups differed in left hypothalamus and left inferior parietal lobule and post hoc analyses revealed that this difference is primarily due to reduced GMV in the PTSD group relative to the other groups. Further analysis revealed that the PTSD group also showed reduced GMV in frontal lobe, temporal lobe, and cerebellum compared to the OCD group, and reduced GMV in frontal lobes bilaterally compared to SAD group. A significant negative correlation with anxiety symptoms is observed for GMV in left hypothalamus in three disorder groups. We have thus found evidence for brain structure differences that in future could provide biomarkers to potentially support classification of these disorders using MRI.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Meets inclusion criteria: English, peer-reviewed MRI voxel-based morphometry study with adult human participants; includes an empirical PTSD group (n=30) and reports gray matter volume differences associated with PTSD. Original data are presented.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study used whole-brain voxel-based morphometry (VBM-DARTEL) of gray matter volume obtained with MRI and reports whole-brain between-group contrasts (PTSD vs healthy controls and PTSD vs other patient groups) with corrected cluster-level results and peak coordinates. The sample includes an adult PTSD group (Wenchuan earthquake survivors) and a trauma-unexposed healthy control group, satisfying the requirement of a PTSD group plus at least one comparison group (trauma-unexposed controls). Results are whole-brain (FWE-corrected) and coordinate-based findings are described, not limited to ROIs. The study is not a treatment-only or ROI-only paper and participants are adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

studies.title: Brain structure in post-traumatic stress disorder: A voxel-based morphometry analysis.
studies.abstract: This study compared the difference in brain structure in 12 mine disaster survivors with chronic post-traumatic stress disorder, 7 cases of improved post-traumatic stress disorder symptoms, and 14 controls who experienced the same mine disaster but did not suffer post-traumatic stress disorder, using the voxel-based morphometry method. The correlation between differences in brain structure and post-traumatic stress disorder symptoms was also investigated. Results showed that the gray matter volume was the highest in the trauma control group, followed by the symptoms-improved group, and the lowest in the chronic post-traumatic stress disorder group. Compared with the symptoms-improved group, the gray matter volume in the lingual gyrus of the right occipital lobe was reduced in the chronic post-traumatic stress disorder group. Compared with the trauma control group, the gray matter volume in the right middle occipital gyrus and left middle frontal gyrus was reduced in the symptoms-improved group. Compared with the trauma control group, the gray matter volume in the left superior parietal lobule and right superior frontal gyrus was reduced in the chronic post-traumatic stress disorder group. The gray matter volume in the left superior parietal lobule was significantly positively correlated with the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory subscale score in the symptoms-improved group and chronic post-traumatic stress disorder group (r = 0.477, P = 0.039). Our findings indicate that (1) chronic post-traumatic stress disorder patients have gray matter structural damage in the prefrontal lobe, occipital lobe, and parietal lobe, (2) after post-traumatic stress, the disorder symptoms are improved and gray matter structural damage is reduced, but cannot recover to the trauma-control level, and (3) the superior parietal lobule is possibly associated with chronic post-traumatic stress disorder. Post-traumatic stress disorder patients exhibit gray matter abnormalities.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Original, peer-reviewed VBM MRI study in adult mine-disaster survivors including a chronic PTSD group; reports gray matter volume differences associated with PTSD across brain regions. Meets all inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria apply from the abstract.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study reports whole-brain voxel-based morphometry (VBM) using MRI and compares a chronic PTSD group (n=12) to a trauma-exposed control group (miners without PTSD, n=14). Adults only (males 18–49) were included. The paper presents whole-brain VBM results (between-group ANOVAs and post-hoc two-sample t-tests with Alphasim correction) describing regional gray matter volume differences for PTSD vs. trauma-exposed controls and PTSD vs. symptoms-improved survivors. It is not an ROI-only study, does not focus solely on treatment/longitudinal effects, and provides between-group voxel-based comparisons relevant to the review objective. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria (VBM whole-brain results, PTSD group plus trauma-exposed comparison, adult sample) and does not violate exclusion criteria.

studies.title: A transdiagnostic neuroanatomical signature of psychiatric illness.
studies.abstract: Despite an increasing focus on transdiagnostic approaches to mental health, it remains unclear whether different diagnostic categories share a common neuronatomical basis. The current investigation sought to investigate whether a transdiagnostic set of structural alterations characterized schizophrenia, depression, post-traumatic stress disorder, and obsessive-compulsive disorder, and determine whether any such alterations reflected markers of psychiatric illness or pre-existing familial vulnerability. A total of 404 patients with a psychiatric diagnosis were recruited (psychosis, n = 129; unipolar depression, n = 92; post-traumatic stress disorder, n = 91; obsessive-compulsive disorder, n = 92) alongside n = 201 healthy controls and n = 20 unaffected first-degree relatives. We collected structural magnetic resonance imaging scans from each participant, and tested for transdiagnostic alterations using Voxel-based morphometry. Inferences were made at p < 0.05 after family-wise error correction for multiple comparisons. The four psychiatric groups relative to healthy controls were all characterized by significantly greater gray matter volume in the putamen (right: z-score: 5.97, p-value < 0.001; left: z-score: 4.97, p-value = 0.001); the volume of this region was positively correlated with severity of symptoms across groups (r = 0.313; p < 0.001). Putamen enlargement was also evident in unaffected relatives compared to healthy controls (right: z-score: 8.13, p-value < 0.001; left: z-score: 9.38, p-value < 0.001). Taken collectively, these findings indicate that increased putamen volume may reflect a transdiagnostic marker of familial vulnerability to psychopathology. This is consistent with emerging conceptualizations of psychiatric illness, in which each disorder is understood as a combination of diagnosis-specific features and a transdiagnostic factor reflecting general psychopathology.
studies.journal: Neuropsychopharmacology : official publication of the American College of Neuropsychopharmacology
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Peer-reviewed original VBM study in adult humans including a PTSD group (n=91). Reports gray matter volume differences (increased putamen volume) present across psychiatric groups including PTSD. Sufficient information in abstract to meet inclusion criteria for structural gray matter alterations associated with PTSD.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Study uses voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume with MRI; includes an adult PTSD group (n=91) and an unexposed healthy control group (n=201); reports whole-brain VBM comparisons (PTSD vs HC included within diagnosis-specific contrasts and in the transdiagnostic inclusive mask) with coordinate-based results (bilateral putamen clusters) surviving whole-brain FWE correction. Not ROI-only, not longitudinal/treatment only, and includes required between-group contrast (PTSD vs trauma-unexposed controls). Therefore meets all inclusion criteria.

studies.title: Decreased premotor cortex volume in victims of urban violence with posttraumatic stress disorder.
studies.abstract: Studies addressing posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) have demonstrated that PTSD patients exhibit structural abnormalities in brain regions that relate to stress regulation and fear responses, such as the hippocampus, amygdala, anterior cingulate cortex, and ventromedial prefrontal cortex. Premotor cortical areas are involved in preparing to respond to a threatening situation and in representing the peripersonal space. Urban violence is an important and pervasive cause of human suffering, especially in large urban centers in the developing world. Violent events, such as armed robbery, are very frequent in certain cities, and these episodes increase the risk of PTSD. Assaultive trauma is characterized by forceful invasion of the peripersonal space; therefore, could this traumatic event be associated with structural alteration of premotor areas in PTSD?
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Peer-reviewed PLoS One (2012) original MRI study in adult victims of urban violence with PTSD reporting decreased premotor cortex gray matter volume (structural differences). Written in English, involves adult humans with PTSD and reports gray matter alterations. No exclusion criteria met.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study meets all inclusion criteria: it used voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter (SPM5 with DARTEL, modulated GM images) from T1 MRI; includes an adult PTSD group (n=16 after exclusions) and a trauma-exposed control group without PTSD (n=16); and reports whole-brain VBM between-group results (significant decreased gray matter volume in ventral premotor cortex and pregenual anterior cingulate in PTSD vs. trauma-exposed controls, p<0.05 FDR-corrected, with clusters described and shown in figures). Although ROI analyses for hippocampus/amygdala were also performed, whole-brain voxelwise results are reported, so the study is not ROI-only. Sample is adult and the paper reports between-group coordinate/cluster results. Limitations (small sample, no non-traumatized control group) do not preclude inclusion per the review criteria. Therefore include.

studies.title: Different regional gray matter loss in recent onset PTSD and non PTSD after a single prolonged trauma exposure.
studies.abstract: Gray matter loss in the limbic structures was found in recent onset post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) patients. In the present study, we measured regional gray matter volume in trauma survivors to verify the hypothesis that stress may cause different regional gray matter loss in trauma survivors with and without recent onset PTSD.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Peer-reviewed PLoS One original study measuring regional gray matter volume in trauma survivors, reports gray matter loss in recent-onset PTSD versus non-PTSD; implies MRI/voxel-based morphometry and includes a PTSD group, matching inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study uses whole-brain voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume (SPM8/DARTEL) and reports cluster-corrected, FWE whole-brain results. Participant groups include recent-onset PTSD (n=10), trauma-exposed non-PTSD (n=10), and trauma-unexposed healthy controls (n=20). The paper reports between-group whole-brain contrasts (PTSD vs. normal controls: decreased left ACC; non-PTSD vs. normal controls: decreased pallidum and pulvinar) with corrected statistics, meeting the requirement for whole-brain, coordinate-based VBM comparisons. Participants are adults and analyses are not ROI-only, longitudinal-only, or treatment-only. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: Assault-related self-blame and its association with PTSD in sexually assaulted women: an MRI inquiry.
studies.abstract: Sexual assault is a frequent interpersonal trauma, which often leads to post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Among other postassault characteristics, self-blame attributions were suggested to play an important role in sexually assaulted individuals' coping and were consistently associated with PTSD in this population. The present study aimed to elucidate the neural underpinnings that may associate self-blame and PTSD in women who experienced sexual assault at adulthood, using structural and resting-state functional MRI. Thirty-eight sexually assaulted women and 24 non-exposed matched controls were studied (mean age: 25 years). Among the sexually assaulted participants, assault-related self-blame was negatively correlated with gray matter volume (GMV) bilaterally in the lingual gyrus and adjacent intracalcarine cortex. GMV in this cluster was also predicted by intrusion symptoms and negative social reactions. Resting-state functional connectivity (rs-FC) of this cluster with the left anterior temporal fusiform cortex significantly differed between PTSD and non-PTSD sexually assaulted participants, and was inversely correlated with intrusion symptoms and with peritraumatic dissociation. Finally, lingual cluster's GMV and rs-FC with the anterior fusiform mediated the association between self-blame and intrusion symptoms across sexually assaulted participants. These findings link assault-related self-blame, disrupted postassault recovery and the neural circuitry involved in the processing of traumatic memories.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Peer-reviewed structural MRI study in adult humans reporting gray matter volume (GMV) findings (VBM-like) correlated with intrusion symptoms and self-blame; includes PTSD and non-PTSD sexually assaulted groups. Abstract does not clearly state whether GMV differences were directly compared by PTSD diagnosis, so full-text review is needed to confirm eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This adult (ages 19–37) MRI study used voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume and reports whole-brain VBM results (FDR-corrected cluster-level; peak MNI coordinates and cluster size) showing decreased lingual gyrus GMV associated with self-blame and differences between PTSD and non-PTSD subgroups. The sample includes trauma-exposed women with PTSD (n≈25 above PCL-5 cutoff) and trauma-exposed non-PTSD subgroup as well as non-exposed controls, and the paper reports between-group comparisons (PTSD vs non-PTSD and NEC). Results are whole-brain, coordinate-based, and adults only. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, non-adult sample, or absence of PTSD group) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Insular cortex involvement in declarative memory deficits in patients with post-traumatic stress disorder.
studies.abstract: Neuroimaging studies have proved that hippocampus relate to the deficient of memory in patients with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Many studies in healthy subjects also shown that insular cortex (IC) be involved in the declarative memory. This study was designed to investigate whether insular cortex is involved in declarative memory deficits in patients with PTSD.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract refers to neuroimaging investigation of insular cortex in PTSD but does not specify MRI modality nor explicitly report gray-matter structural (VBM) results. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion/exclusion based on abstract alone; include for full-text review to determine whether structural gray matter differences were reported.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study used voxel-based morphometry (VBM) on MRI to compare gray-matter density between a PTSD group (n=12) and a trauma-exposed non-PTSD comparison group (n=12). Whole-brain VBM results are reported, including Talairach coordinates and T-scores for reduced gray matter in PTSD (e.g., bilateral insula, left medial frontal gyrus), satisfying the requirement for coordinate-based, whole-brain between-group contrasts. Participants are adults and the study is not ROI-only, treatment-only, longitudinal-only, or limited to non-adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

studies.title: Reduced amygdala volume is associated with deficits in inhibitory control: a voxel- and surface-based morphometric analysis of comorbid PTSD/mild TBI.
studies.abstract: A significant portion of previously deployed combat Veterans from Operation Enduring Freedom and Operation Iraqi Freedom/Operation New Dawn (OEF/OIF/OND) are affected by comorbid posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI). Despite this fact, neuroimaging studies investigating the neural correlates of cognitive dysfunction within this population are almost nonexistent, with the exception of research examining the neural correlates of diagnostic PTSD or TBI. The current study used both voxel-based and surface-based morphometry to determine whether comorbid PTSD/mTBI is characterized by altered brain structure in the same regions as observed in singular diagnostic PTSD or TBI. Furthermore, we assessed whether alterations in brain structures in these regions were associated with behavioral measures related to inhibitory control, as assessed by the Go/No-go task, self-reports of impulsivity, and/or PTSD or mTBI symptoms. Results indicate volumetric reductions in the bilateral anterior amygdala in our comorbid PTSD/mTBI sample as compared to a control sample of OEF/OIF Veterans with no history of mTBI and/or PTSD. Moreover, increased volume reduction in the amygdala predicted poorer inhibitory control as measured by performance on the Go/No-go task, increased self-reported impulsivity, and greater symptoms associated with PTSD. These findings suggest that alterations in brain anatomy in OEF/OIF/OND Veterans with comorbid PTSD/mTBI are associated with both cognitive deficits and trauma symptoms related to PTSD.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Peer-reviewed MRI study of adult OEF/OIF veterans including a PTSD+mTBI group; original VBM and surface-based morphometry reporting gray matter (amygdala) volumetric reductions associated with PTSD symptoms and inhibitory-control deficits. Meets all inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study reports whole-brain voxel-based morphometry (FSL-VBM) analyses comparing an adult group with PTSD (comorbid PTSD/mTBI; N=21) to a trauma-exposed deployed control group without PTSD or mTBI (N=16). Whole-brain VBM results (TFCE-corrected, 5000 permutations) showing reduced bilateral anterior amygdala volume in the PTSD/mTBI group are described, and surface-based morphometry was used to corroborate VBM findings. The sample is adult (ages 18–45). Although the PTSD group is comorbid with mTBI, inclusion criteria required at least one PTSD group and at least one comparison group (met here), and comorbidity is not an exclusion in the stated criteria. The paper provides whole-brain VBM between-group results and links them to behavioral measures, satisfying the meta-analysis inclusion criteria.

studies.title: Social support modulates the association between PTSD diagnosis and medial frontal volume in Chinese adults who lost their only child.
studies.abstract: Losing an only child is a devastating life event that a parent can experience and may lead to post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Social support could buffer against the negative influence of this trauma, but the neural mechanism underlying this alleviation effect remains poorly understood. In this study, voxel-based morphometry was conducted on brain MRI of 220 Han Chinese adults who had lost their only child. We performed multiple regression analysis to investigate the associations between social support scores - along with PTSD diagnosis, age, sex, body mass index (BMI) - and brain grey matter (GM) volumes in these bereaved parents. For all trauma-exposed adults, social support-by-diagnosis interaction was significantly associated with medial prefrontal volume (multiple comparisons corrected
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Peer-reviewed MRI study in English with original data on adult humans (n=220) including individuals with PTSD; uses voxel-based morphometry reporting gray matter volume associations (medial prefrontal/medial frontal) related to PTSD diagnosis and interactions with social support, meeting all inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study used voxel-based morphometry (SPM12/CAT12) on high-resolution T1 MRI and reports whole-brain, voxel-wise results comparing adults with PTSD (n=57) to trauma-exposed non-PTSD adults (n=163). Whole-brain GM volume differences (e.g., reduced medial and middle frontal gyri in PTSD) are reported with coordinates/figures and corrected/uncorrected thresholds. Sample consists of adults, not treatment or longitudinal-only, and analyses are whole-brain rather than ROI-only. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for VBM whole-brain comparisons of PTSD vs trauma-exposed controls.

studies.title: Using structural neuroanatomy to identify trauma survivors with and without post-traumatic stress disorder at the individual level.
studies.abstract: At present there are no objective, biological markers that can be used to reliably identify individuals with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). This study assessed the diagnostic potential of structural magnetic resonance imaging (sMRI) for identifying trauma-exposed individuals with and without PTSD.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Peer-reviewed study using structural MRI to distinguish trauma-exposed individuals with and without PTSD, reporting original data on structural neuroanatomy (likely gray matter/voxel-based analyses) in adults; meets inclusion criteria for gray matter structural differences associated with PTSD.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study uses voxel-based morphometry methods (SPM8 segmentation, modulation, smoothing of GM and WM) on structural MRI and reports whole-brain voxel-wise mass-univariate results and multivariate SVM results. Sample includes adults: 50 PTSD, 50 trauma-exposed without PTSD, and 40 trauma-unexposed healthy controls. The paper reports whole-brain VBM comparisons (PTSD vs healthy controls; PTSD vs trauma-exposed without PTSD; trauma-exposed without PTSD vs healthy controls) with FWE-corrected findings and supplementary tables of regions/coordinates (Tables S3–S9). Thus it meets all inclusion criteria (VBM measurement, appropriate groups, whole-brain voxel-based results). No exclusion criteria are met.

abstract_screening_results.reason: Abstract reads as a narrative review of neurobiology of emotional trauma and references meta-analyses and neuroimaging findings but does not report original MRI data, specific adult PTSD sample, or gray-matter VBM results. Meets exclusion: non-empirical/review without original MRI data.

Abstract reads as a review summarizing prior MRI findings rather than reporting original empirical MRI data. No sample, methods, or voxel-based morphometry results are described; thus it meets the exclusion criterion for non-empirical papers.

Abstract states this is a review article discussing literature; it does not report original MRI data or voxel-based morphometry results in PTSD. As a non-empirical review, it meets the exclusion criterion.

This is a review article summarizing neuroimaging findings rather than reporting original MRI data. It does not present primary gray-matter structural (voxel-based morphometry) results from adult PTSD participants, so it meets exclusion criteria for non-empirical papers.

This article is a meta-analysis synthesizing voxel-based morphometry studies rather than reporting original MRI data from adult PTSD participants. Per the exclusion criteria, non-empirical papers/meta-analyses without original MRI data should be excluded.

Abstract appears to address stress resilience broadly and seems to be a non-empirical/review or theoretical paper. It does not report original MRI data nor mention adult PTSD patient groups or voxel-based gray matter findings required for inclusion.

This article is a voxelwise meta-analysis/systematic review of VBM studies and does not report original MRI data from adult participants. It is a non-empirical secondary analysis, meeting the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses without original data.

Abstract identifies this work as a review of neural mechanisms underlying TBI and PTSD, not an empirical MRI study. It does not report original human MRI data or voxel-based gray matter analyses, so it meets exclusion criteria for non-empirical papers.

This is a review/ translational perspective discussing animal and human findings; it does not report original human MRI (voxel-based morphometry) data. Therefore it meets exclusion for non-empirical papers without original MRI data.

This is a narrative/theoretical review on pain, reward and suicidality, not an empirical MRI study. It does not report original VBM or other gray-matter structural MRI results nor include PTSD patient groups. Excluded per criteria (non-empirical, no PTSD MRI gray-matter data).

Abstract describes a review of frontal lobe circuitry in PTSD rather than reporting original MRI data. It explicitly frames as a review and does not present new VBM/gray-matter findings in adult PTSD participants. Excluded as a non-empirical review per criteria.

This paper is a meta-analysis/review summarizing structural MRI findings across studies and does not present original participant-level MRI data. Excluded per criterion: non-empirical papers (meta-analyses) without original MRI data.

Abstract reports diffusion tensor imaging (white matter) results and correlations with previously reported VBM values; it does not present original voxel‑based morphometry/gray matter structural findings. Therefore it meets the exclusion criterion of reporting only white matter structural differences.

Abstract reports MRI-measured smaller hippocampal volume in adults with PTSD and treatment studies showing hippocampal volume changes. These are gray-matter structural findings in PTSD. However, it is unclear from the abstract whether this paper is an original empirical MRI study or a review and whether voxel-based morphometry was used. Include for full-text review to confirm original adult MRI gray-matter data and methods.

Abstract reports a pediatric PTSD sample (children/adolescents). Inclusion criteria require adult human samples; therefore the study should be excluded. The study otherwise uses MRI and reports grey matter network alterations, but the population is not adult.

This paper is a systematic review and meta-analysis focusing on white matter integrity using DTI, not an original empirical MRI study reporting gray matter (VBM) differences in adults with PTSD. It thus meets exclusion criteria (review; white-matter focus).

Abstract describes a review/discussion and computational modeling paper using examples (including PTSD) and does not report original MRI data or voxel-based morphometry results among adult PTSD patients. Meets exclusion for non-empirical paper.

Abstract reports MRI-based gray matter (cortical thickness) findings and correlations with PTSD measures but does not clearly state a distinct PTSD group. Because it may report PTSD-related structural alterations yet lacks explicit group description, include for full-text review to determine whether an adult PTSD group or PTSD-specific analyses are reported.

Abstract presents a hypothesis/conceptual discussion about blast-induced mTBI/PTSD and does not report original MRI data or voxel-based gray matter findings in adult PTSD patients. It appears non-empirical, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Pediatric sample (ages 8–15) not adult humans; study examines post-traumatic stress symptoms after injury rather than a PTSD patient group, and focuses on microstructure of prefrontal-limbic circuitry (likely diffusion/white-matter measures) rather than gray matter VBM. Fails required inclusion criteria.

Non-empirical review/theoretical paper focused on schizophrenia and microglial mechanisms. Does not report original MRI data, does not include adult PTSD participants, and does not report gray-matter VBM findings related to PTSD.

Study uses diffusion tensor imaging to report white matter integrity (corpus callosum FA) and does not report gray matter structural differences (e.g., VBM). Meets exclusion criterion for studies reporting only white matter findings.

Study investigates pediatric (child/adolescent) PTSD rather than adult humans. Inclusion criteria require adult samples; therefore excluded. Abstract indicates longitudinal pediatric sample, so exclusion is clear from abstract.

Abstract indicates structural and functional brain alterations in PTSD but does not specify MRI methods, sample characteristics, or that gray matter (voxel-based morphometry) results are reported. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to determine if original adult human MRI VBM gray-matter findings are reported.

MRI study of adult sexually assaulted women examining macro- and microstructure of gray-matter regions (amygdala, hippocampus, ACC, insula). However, the abstract does not specify whether participants had PTSD. Insufficient information to confirm PTSD group presence — include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Peer-reviewed MRI study of adult humans with PTSD (combat veterans) reporting original data. Uses Freesurfer to quantify hippocampal volumes (gray matter structural measure) and reports associations between PTSD duration and hippocampal volume, meeting the review objective of structural brain alterations in PTSD.

Peer-reviewed original volumetric MRI study in adult humans including a PTSD group; reports gray matter structural differences (cortical thickness and subcortical volumes) associated with PTSD. Abstract meets inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria are met.

Meets inclusion criteria: English, peer-reviewed MRI study with adult human participants including a PTSD group, reports original data and gray matter structural measures (cortical thickness and subcortical volumes). No exclusion criteria apparent.

Peer-reviewed original MRI study in English using voxel-based morphometry on adult humans with a PTSD group and matched controls; reports gray matter volume reductions (hippocampus, amygdala, ACC, frontal regions) associated with PTSD. No exclusion criteria met.

Peer-reviewed MRI study of adult combat-exposed U.S. veterans including at least one PTSD group; reports original data and vertex-wise cortical thickness (gray matter structural) reductions associated with PTSD and symptom severity, meeting inclusion criteria.

It does not report original adult human MRI data or gray-matter structural (VBM) findings for PTSD. Therefore it meets exclusion criteria (non-empirical review without original MRI data).

This is a systematic review/meta-analysis of pediatric (children/adolescents) PTSD MRI studies, not original primary data from adult humans. It therefore fails the sample criterion (not adults) and does not report original adult gray matter structural results required for inclusion.

Peer-reviewed structural MRI study of adult humans reporting gray matter regional volumes (hippocampus, amygdala, prefrontal regions) associated with persistent PTS symptoms. It is unclear whether a distinct PTSD group comparison was performed; include for full-text review to confirm group-based analyses and VBM/voxelwise or volumetric gray-matter results.

Meets inclusion criteria: English peer-reviewed original MRI study in adult humans (15 DSM-IV PTSD patients) using voxel-based morphometry reporting gray matter volume differences correlated with PTSD severity. No exclusion criteria (not non-empirical, not white-matter-only) are met.

Abstract does not mention PTSD or any adult PTSD group; focuses on morphometric methods and developmental/anatomic variability in typical/atypical brain development (likely pediatric) and appears to be an overview/prototype database rather than original VBM results reporting gray matter differences associated with PTSD.

It therefore does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring original gray-matter structural (VBM) results and meets the exclusion criterion for non-empirical reviews.

Study used healthy young female subjects in an experimental trauma film paradigm and did not include any group of individuals with PTSD. Inclusion criteria require at least one PTSD group, so this study does not meet the sample requirement.

Participants are youth aged 9–17 (pediatric sample), whereas the review requires adult human samples. Also reports regional amygdala volumetry in children/adolescents rather than adult VBM gray-matter differences. Excluded based on population criterion.
Study sample comprises adolescents (minors) with PTSD; inclusion criteria require adult human samples. Although it reports gray-matter measures, the age criterion is not met.

This paper is a quantitative meta-analysis of voxel-based morphometry studies rather than an original empirical MRI study reporting primary data. Excluded per criterion: non-empirical meta-analyses without original MRI data.

Study investigates cortical thickness in functional neurological disorder (somatoform/psychological dissociation) and does not include a PTSD patient group; therefore it does not meet the requirement of reporting structural differences associated with PTSD.

Study examines cortical thickness in mild TBI vs non-mTBI MVC survivors and assesses traumatic stress symptoms, but does not include a group of individuals with PTSD or report gray-matter differences associated with a PTSD diagnosis. Structural MRI study reporting cortical folding (local gyrification index) differences in PTSD patients after motor vehicle accidents — indicates gray matter cortical morphology alterations. Published in a peer-reviewed journal and reports original data with a PTSD group. Adult sample likely given context; abstract supports inclusion for review of gray matter structural differences.

Meets inclusion criteria: English, peer-reviewed MRI voxel-based morphometry study with adult human participants; includes an empirical PTSD group (n=30) and reports gray matter volume differences associated with PTSD. Original data are presented.

Peer-reviewed MRI study of adult unmedicated PTSD patients vs healthy controls reporting habenula gray matter volume differences (structural MRI). Original empirical data in English; matches inclusion criteria for gray matter structural differences associated with PTSD.

This publication is a meta-analysis/systematic review and does not present original MRI data from participants. Exclusion criterion disallows non-empirical papers (reviews/meta-analyses) without original MRI data.

Abstract describes an MRI study of PTSD patients (with alcoholism) examining volumes of hippocampus, amygdala, and prefrontal cortex—suggesting gray matter structural measures in adult humans. However methods/results are not specified (e.g., VBM vs ROI). Insufficient detail to confirm all inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review to verify.

Original, peer-reviewed VBM MRI study in adult mine-disaster survivors including a chronic PTSD group; reports gray matter volume differences associated with PTSD across brain regions. Meets all inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria apply from the abstract.

Abstract reports an original study of regional brain volumes in adult combat veterans assessing associations with PTSD (and deployment TBI). This likely involves structural MRI but does not specify voxel-based morphometry or explicitly gray matter results. Insufficient detail to confirm VBM/gray-matter-only reporting, so include for full-text review.

The study reports original structural MRI volumetric analyses in adult IPV survivors and measures post-traumatic stress, but the abstract does not state a PTSD-diagnosed group. Because it’s unclear whether a PTSD group is present, include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

This is a narrative review article summarizing neuroimaging literature rather than reporting original MRI data among adult PTSD patients. It does not present original VBM/gray-matter findings, meeting the exclusion criterion for non-empirical papers.

Abstract reports analysis of brain volumes in a PTSD sample relating structural abnormalities to flashbacks/symptoms, indicating original peer-reviewed structural MRI research in PTSD. Abstract lacks explicit VBM/adult-sample wording; include for full-text review to confirm methods and gray matter results.

Abstract states the study tests volumetric brain morphology differences in the dissociative subtype of PTSD, implying structural (grey matter) analysis in adult PTSD patients. It appears to report original, peer-reviewed neuroimaging data relevant to gray matter alterations. Full text should be checked to confirm MRI/voxel-based morphometry methods and adult sample, but abstract provides sufficient grounds to include for full-text review.

Peer-reviewed structural MRI study of adult humans with PTSD vs trauma-exposed controls, original data. Reports gray-matter network/topological differences (reduced clustering coefficient) associated with PTSD, meeting the review’s criterion for gray-matter structural alterations.

Abstract examines cortical thickness related to interpersonal trauma in HIV+ adults and likely reports original MRI data, but it does not mention PTSD or a PTSD group. Because PTSD status is unclear from the abstract, include for full-text review to determine whether PTSD groups and gray matter (VBM/thickness) results are reported.

Peer-reviewed MRI volumetric study reporting grey matter reductions associated with PTSD (contrasted with major depression); includes at least one PTSD group of adult humans and reports original VBM-like analyses. Abstract sufficiently indicates inclusion criteria met.

Peer-reviewed original MRI study in adults including a PTSD group. Structural MRI gray matter volume (GMV) was extracted and used as a classification feature, indicating reporting of gray-matter structural measures relevant to PTSD. Satisfies inclusion criteria for gray matter structural differences.

Abstract does not describe an MRI study or report gray-matter structural differences (e.g., VBM). It focuses on tau accumulation (likely PET or postmortem) in veterans with TBI/PTSD; therefore it does not meet the MRI gray-matter structural alteration inclusion criteria.

Abstract studies associations between subjective sleep quality and brain volume in Gulf War veterans; it does not mention inclusion of a PTSD group or report gray-matter structural differences associated with PTSD. Does not meet the requirement of reporting PTSD-related gray matter alterations.

Abstract describes methodological comparison of automated vs manual segmentation of hippocampus and amygdala in a general sample (n=92). No mention of PTSD participants or PTSD-related gray matter differences. Does not report original data on structural alterations associated with PTSD.

Peer-reviewed MRI study in adults with combat-related PTSD reporting original longitudinal data showing hippocampal gray-matter increases pre- to post-therapy. This directly reports gray matter structural differences associated with PTSD and meets inclusion criteria.

Peer-reviewed voxel-based morphometry MRI study in adults including a PTSD group and traumatized controls; reports gray matter volume alterations related to trait dissociation and their relationship with PTSD, meeting inclusion criteria for gray matter structural differences associated with PTSD.

Study reports MRI-based cortical structural networks in adult recent-onset PTSD patients vs controls, describing regional gray-matter network/structural connectivity alterations. Abstract does not specify voxel-based morphometry, so methods are unclear; include for full-text review to confirm that gray matter structural differences (e.g., VBM or comparable measures) are reported.

Meets inclusion: peer-reviewed MRI study in English with adult PTSD sample reporting original data on smaller cerebral cortical gray matter volume (structural gray matter differences). Aligns with review objective; no exclusion criteria evident from abstract.

Abstract describes a conceptual/review paper on synaptic plasticity and dopamine in psychiatric disorders; it does not report original MRI data or adult human voxel-based morphometry findings. Meets exclusion criterion for non-empirical papers without original MRI data.

This is a systematic review (non-empirical) of MRI studies on dissociative experiences, not an original MRI study reporting primary data in adult PTSD patients or gray matter VBM results. Excluded per criterion: non-empirical papers without original MRI data.

Study sample comprises pediatric/youth participants (27 PTSD youth and 27 healthy youth), not adult humans as required by the inclusion criteria. Although it reports gray matter volume differences using MRI/voxel-based morphometry, it fails the ‘adult humans’ sample requirement.

This article is a meta-analysis summarizing hippocampal volumetric studies rather than reporting original MRI data from adult participants. Exclusion criterion: non-empirical papers/meta-analyses without original MRI data is met.

The article is a brief review of structural neuroimaging in children/adolescents with PTSD, not an original empirical MRI study. It does not report adult human VBM gray-matter results and appears to synthesize published studies. Therefore it meets exclusion criteria for non-empirical/review paper and for focusing on pediatric white/structural findings rather than original adult gray-matter VBM data.

Peer-reviewed English structural MRI study reporting original data comparing recent-onset PTSD patients with trauma-exposed and non-exposed controls; abstract specifically reports gray matter reductions (structural differences). No exclusion criteria met.

English, peer-reviewed MRI study of adult Vietnam Veterans including individuals with PTSD; reports original data using surface-based morphometry and finds gray matter volume and shape differences (dmPFC and amygdala) associated with PTSD. Meets inclusion criteria for structural gray matter alterations.

Abstract reports structural changes (amygdala volume and ACC) in recent-onset PTSD, indicating original, peer-reviewed MRI data on gray matter differences in adult patients. This matches the review inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to confirm methods (e.g., VBM vs volumetry) and sample details.

Peer-reviewed MRI study of adult (male) combat veterans with PTSD and controls reporting original data. Structural MRI results show reduced left occipital gray matter volume in PTSD correlated with symptom severity, fulfilling the requirement for gray matter structural differences. No exclusion criteria met.

The abstract describes a narrative review of neuroimaging in TBI among veterans, not an original empirical MRI study. It does not report original data or PTSD-specific gray matter (voxel-based) findings. Per exclusion criteria (non-empirical reviews), exclude.

Peer-reviewed structural MRI study in adult women with chronic PTSD vs matched controls reporting original data. Uses automated cortical thickness and subcortical volumetric analyses (gray matter measures). Although findings are null, the study assesses gray matter structure in PTSD and should be included for full-text review to confirm methods (VBM or equivalent) and extract data.

Peer-reviewed original MRI study in adults measuring regional brain volumes (e.g., hippocampus, amygdala) at 2 weeks post-injury and reporting that these gray matter volumes predict PTSD at 3 and 6 months, meeting inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports GWAS of subcortical brain volumes in adult PTSD cases and controls but does not clearly state voxel‑based morphometry or explicit gray matter structural differences associated with PTSD. Insufficient information to confirm VBM/GM results from abstract alone; include for full-text review to verify whether gray matter structural comparisons (VBM) are reported.

The study examined 42 non-PTSD subjects and did not include any group of individuals with diagnosed PTSD. Although it reports grey matter volume associations with PTSD symptoms, it lacks a PTSD patient group required by inclusion criteria.

This paper is a systematic review and quantitative meta-analysis of MRI studies and does not report original MRI data. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for non-empirical/meta-analytic papers without original MRI data.

Sample consists of adolescents with CSA-related PTSD (pediatric population), whereas the meta-analysis inclusion criteria require adult human samples. Although it reports VBM GMV findings, the age group does not meet the adult-sample requirement.

Peer-reviewed MRI study of adult civilians with PTSD reporting reduced hippocampal volume (a gray-matter structural finding) and whole-brain measures. Original data and adult PTSD group are present. VBM not specified but hippocampal gray-matter result warrants inclusion for full-text review.

Peer-reviewed original MRI volumetric study in adult humans with PTSD reporting smaller hippocampal gray matter volume. Co-twin case-control provides original data and addresses structural brain alterations associated with PTSD. No exclusion criteria met.

Abstract investigates gray matter volume in relation to combat-related PTSD in OEF/OIF veterans, implying structural brain (MRI) analysis and original data. While it does not explicitly state MRI methods or explicit PTSD group in the abstract, it addresses PTSD-related gray matter changes; insufficient detail to exclude. Include for full-text review to confirm MRI VBM methods and presence of a PTSD group.

Peer-reviewed MRI study of adult humans (women) with PTSD vs trauma-exposed controls reporting original data. Abstract describes gray matter volumetric reductions in pregenual ACC and subcallosal cortex (cortical structural differences) associated with PTSD, meeting inclusion criteria.

The study sample comprises children and adolescents (pediatric), whereas the review requires studies of adult humans with PTSD. Although MRI hippocampal volumes are reported, the age criterion is not met.

Peer-reviewed MRI study of adult US military veterans including individuals with remitted PTSD; reports cortical thickness–based structural covariance/network topology (gray matter structural measures). Original empirical cross-sectional data addressing structural brain alterations associated with PTSD. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for the review.

NeuroImage Clinical original MRI study in adults examining relationships between PTSD symptom severity and gray matter limbic/paralimbic microstructure; includes PTSD group and reports gray matter structural associations (not limited to white matter). Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion for full data extraction.

Original peer-reviewed human study with T1-weighted MRI cortical thickness data and adult PTSD and trauma-exposed groups. Abstract reports cortical atrophy (gray matter) in relation to GrimAge acceleration but does not explicitly state PTSD-related gray matter differences. Insufficient detail in abstract to confirm exclusion, so include for full-text review to determine whether PTSD-associated structural differences are reported.

This paper is a meta-analysis of voxel-based morphometry studies and does not present original MRI data. Exclusion criterion disallows non-empirical papers (reviews/meta-analyses) without original MRI data, so it should be excluded despite reporting gray matter findings.

Peer-reviewed original VBM study in adult humans including a PTSD group (n=91). Reports gray matter volume differences (increased putamen volume) present across psychiatric groups including PTSD. Sufficient information in abstract to meet inclusion criteria for structural gray matter alterations associated with PTSD.

Study uses an animal model (single-prolonged stress) rather than adult human participants with PTSD; does not report MRI results in human PTSD groups or original human voxel-based morphometry comparisons. Therefore it does not meet the sample criteria.

Not an MRI study of PTSD: abstract discusses PFC dysfunction in bipolar disorder and schizophrenia; no mention of PTSD, MRI methods, or original voxel-based gray matter findings. Appears non-empirical/theoretical, so fails inclusion criteria.

This is a review linking child abuse, sex differences, and animal studies; it does not report original adult human MRI data, does not mention PTSD patient groups, nor report gray-matter VBM results. Therefore it fails multiple inclusion criteria.

The study examines cortical thickness differences between blast and non-blast persistent mild TBI subjects and does not include or report data on individuals with PTSD. Inclusion criteria require at least one PTSD group; thus it does not meet the review’s PTSD-specific sample requirement.

The study investigates mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI) in veterans and reports cortical curvature/atrophy related to mTBI. It does not include any PTSD group or report gray matter structural differences associated with PTSD, so it does not meet the review’s inclusion criteria.

Study examines maltreated children (pediatric sample) rather than adult humans and does not report data from a PTSD group; therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria requiring adult participants with PTSD-related gray matter differences.

This is a review article summarizing neuronal-circuit and optogenetic findings; it does not report original MRI data in adult humans or voxel-based morphometry results related to PTSD. It is non-empirical for our meta-analysis objective.

Abstract reads like a narrative review of neuroimaging findings in childhood trauma rather than an original MRI study. It does not report original data, sample details, or voxel-based gray matter analyses in adult PTSD patients; focus is on children/childhood trauma. Meets exclusion for non-empirical/review and insufficient adult-PTSD gray-matter MRI data.

Peer-reviewed MRI study of adults with PTSD reporting original data measuring ACC gray-matter area/volumes using semi-automated MRI-based methods. Addresses structural brain alterations associated with PTSD; although not voxel-based morphometry specifically, it reports gray-matter volumetric measures relevant to inclusion criteria.

Peer-reviewed structural MRI study in adult veterans with PTSD reporting amygdala (gray matter) volume differences; original data; fits review objective of structural brain alterations in PTSD. Abstract indicates volumetric gray-matter findings.

Peer-reviewed longitudinal MRI study (3D T1) with adult PTSD and control groups reporting original data. Uses deformation morphometry to quantify brain volume/atrophy across frontal, temporal and other regions, i.e. macrostructural gray-matter changes associated with PTSD. Meets inclusion criteria for structural brain alterations in adult PTSD.

The study reports within-group associations between rumination and regional gray matter volume in women with PTSD but does not report gray matter structural differences associated with PTSD (e.g., PTSD vs control VBM or group contrasts). Thus it does not meet the criterion requiring gray matter structural differences associated with PTSD.

Sample consists of adolescents (ages 14–18), not adults, and includes healthy youths without a PTSD group. The study examines community violence exposure, not PTSD-related gray matter differences among adults, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Study involves mild TBI patients and healthy controls and does not include any group of individuals with diagnosed PTSD. Although cortical thickness and PTSD symptom ratings are reported, the study does not report gray matter differences associated with PTSD diagnosis, so it fails the requirement of including a PTSD group.

Animal study using a mouse model of PTSD (MEMRI and ex vivo measures). Inclusion requires original MRI data from adult humans with PTSD reporting gray matter structural differences. This study is non-human, so it does not meet the population criterion.

Abstract states the sample is trauma-exposed firefighters without PTSD; inclusion requires at least one group with PTSD and reporting gray matter structural differences. No PTSD group or VBM/gray matter results are reported in the abstract, so exclude.

Meets inclusion criteria: English, peer-reviewed Radiology article reporting original 3T MRI data in adult PTSD patients versus trauma-exposed controls; reports gray-matter structural differences (increased cortical thickness and subcortical/callosal volumes) associated with PTSD and severity. Not excluded for white-matter–only findings.

Abstract examines cortical thickness in relation to PTSD-related metabolic syndrome and polygenic risk, but does not explicitly state MRI methods or report gray-matter (VBM) differences directly attributable to PTSD. Insufficient detail in abstract to confirm all inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to determine MRI modality, adult PTSD group comparisons, and gray-matter structural findings.

Peer-reviewed MRI study of adult humans including a PTSD group with original data. Reports structural gray-matter-derived findings (cortical thickness structural covariance networks) showing differences in PTSD vs controls. Not limited to white matter; addresses structural brain alterations associated with PTSD.

The abstract examines associations of early life stress/ACE with adult brain volumes, but does not mention participants with PTSD or a PTSD group. Inclusion requires at least one group with PTSD; therefore exclude.

Study reports post-traumatic growth neural correlates in healthy young survivors and delta rGMV, but does not include or compare an adult PTSD group or report gray matter differences associated with PTSD. Therefore it fails the key inclusion criterion.

Abstract reports original MRI-based analysis of regional brain volumes (hippocampal volumetric changes) in PTSD patients versus healthy controls, indicating gray matter structural differences. Published in an English peer-reviewed journal and involves adult clinical group. Sufficient information to meet inclusion for full-text review.

Study examines borderline personality disorder (BPD), not PTSD; no PTSD group is included. Additionally, this is a meta-analysis of BPD MRI studies (non-original data) and does not report gray-matter VBM findings associated with PTSD.

Although the sample included participants with PTSD, the study examines mild TBI and Alzheimer’s genetic risk in relation to cortical thickness and memory. The abstract does not report gray-matter structural differences associated with PTSD or a PTSD vs control analysis. It therefore does not meet the criterion of reporting GM structural differences associated with PTSD.

Peer-reviewed structural MRI study in adult Veterans reporting original data; includes PTSD assessment and reports gray matter (cortical thickness) differences associated with PTSD (reduced thickness in right fusiform). Meets inclusion criteria for structural gray-matter alterations related to PTSD.

Abstract investigates structural correlates of resilience in police officers and does not mention inclusion of a PTSD group or report gray-matter differences associated with PTSD. Does not meet requirement of at least one PTSD group.

Abstract reports MRI volumetric assessment of hippocampus and amygdala in ICU survivors and examines association with PTSD symptoms, matching the review objective. However it does not clearly state a diagnosed PTSD group or explicit VBM methods, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Peer-reviewed original MRI study in adult veterans including individuals with PTSD; reports cortical thickness (a gray-matter structural measure) associated with PTSD and related analyses. Fits inclusion criteria for structural gray-matter alterations.

This paper is a systematic review of MRI findings in anxiety disorders, not an original empirical MRI study reporting new gray matter (VBM) data in adults with PTSD. It does not present primary data for PTSD-specific structural brain differences, so it meets exclusion criteria for non-empirical/review articles.

Study does not include a PTSD group. Participants were young adults who witnessed domestic violence and had no current/past DSM-IV Axis I or II disorder. Therefore it does not meet the requirement of having at least one PTSD group.

Sample consists of maltreated youth (pediatric participants), while the review requires studies of adult humans. Although MRI and gray-matter volume differences are reported, the age criterion is not met.

Peer-reviewed MRI study of adult (combat-exposed) veterans with PTSD reporting structural cortical and subcortical imaging markers. Contains original data. Abstract does not explicitly state voxel-based morphometry/gray matter metrics, so include for full-text review to confirm specific gray matter measures.

Peer-reviewed MRI study of adult chronic PTSD patients vs controls reporting hippocampal volume changes (gray-matter) using two evaluation methods. Original data in English. Abstract does not explicitly state VBM but reports gray-matter volume differences associated with PTSD, so included for full-text review to confirm methods and details.

Peer-reviewed VBM study in adult humans reporting original MRI data; includes a subgroup of BPD patients with comorbid PTSD and explicitly reports gray-matter volume differences associated with co-occurring PTSD, meeting the review’s inclusion criteria.

Peer-reviewed MRI study in English reporting original volumetric data from adult combat-exposed veterans including individuals with PTSD; assesses gray-matter hippocampal subfield volumes associated with PTSD/depression. Meets all inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria apparent from abstract.

Peer-reviewed MRI study with adult trauma-exposed veterans including PTSD measures; reports original data and whole-brain vertex-wise cortical thickness findings (gray-matter structural differences) associated with PTSD. Meets inclusion criteria.

This paper is a meta-analysis of gray matter volumes across PTSD and AUD and does not present original MRI data. Per exclusion criteria, non-empirical/meta-analytic studies without original MRI data should be excluded.

The study investigates MRI morphometry to predict 12-month outcomes after mild traumatic brain injury, not PTSD. Abstract does not include any PTSD group or report gray-matter structural differences associated with PTSD. Therefore it does not meet the review’s PTSD-related inclusion criteria.

Adult MRI study reporting original data on cortical thickness and subcortical volumes (gray matter morphometry) in relation to PTSD symptom severity among deployed service members. Uses clinician-assessed PTSD symptoms and FreeSurfer structural measures, which meet the review objective. Include for full-text review to confirm presence of a PTSD group and detailed VBM-type analyses.
Sample comprises youth aged 8–18 years (pediatric sample). Inclusion criteria require studies among adult humans; therefore the study does not meet the adult-sample criterion.

Abstract reports multimodal MRI structural covariance linked to acute posttraumatic stress severity but does not specify adult sample, presence of a PTSD diagnostic group, or explicit gray-matter/VBM results. Insufficient detail to determine inclusion—include for full-text review.

Abstract states use of structural MRI in PTSD patients but does not specify reporting of gray-matter structural differences or VBM results. Insufficient information in abstract to confirm inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to determine whether gray matter (voxel-based) structural differences associated with PTSD are reported.

This is a dual meta-analysis (secondary synthesis) rather than an original empirical MRI study reporting primary gray-matter VBM data in PTSD patients; thus it fails the inclusion criterion requiring original data.

Although the study uses voxel-wise gray matter volumes, it compares treatment responders vs non-responders within a PTSD sample rather than reporting gray-matter structural differences associated with PTSD diagnosis (e.g., PTSD vs controls). Abstract lacks evidence of VBM differences tied to PTSD itself. Exclude based on meta-analysis criteria.

Abstract reports adult female victims with and without PTSD and examines neuroanatomical morphometry (structural brain measures), so it addresses PTSD-related structural brain alterations. However, the abstract does not explicitly state MRI modality or that gray matter/VBM results are reported. Insufficient detail to confirm gray matter-specific findings — include for full-text review.

Peer-reviewed MRI study in adult humans reporting smaller hippocampal (gray matter) volume in police officers with PTSD versus traumatized controls; original data and in English. No exclusion criteria met.
This is an animal (mouse) study of stress-induced grey matter changes, not a study of adult humans with PTSD. No human participants or PTSD group are reported, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.
Peer-reviewed MRI study of adult recent-onset PTSD with original data reporting smaller hippocampal volumes (gray matter structural differences). Meets inclusion criteria; no exclusion criteria met.

This is a literature review summarizing MRI hippocampal volumetry across disorders rather than reporting original MRI data. It does not present an original PTSD patient sample or primary voxel-based gray matter analyses, so it meets the exclusion criterion for non-empirical papers.

The study examines hippocampal subfields in women with borderline personality disorder explicitly without PTSD; it does not include any group of individuals with PTSD, so it fails the inclusion criterion requiring a PTSD group.

English-language peer-reviewed MRI study of adult humans with a PTSD group and trauma-exposed controls reporting original data. Uses FreeSurfer to extract hippocampal/subfield gray-matter volumes (structural measures). Although results were null, the study reports gray matter structural measures associated with PTSD and therefore meets inclusion; include for full-text review.

The study reports volumetric MRI measurements of the pituitary gland, not gray-matter structural differences using voxel-based morphometry. Inclusion criteria require studies reporting gray matter structural differences (e.g., VBM). Therefore it does not meet the key imaging/analysis criterion for inclusion.

This is a meta-analysis of voxel-based morphometry in obsessive-compulsive disorder (not PTSD) and thus does not report original MRI data on PTSD patients. It does not include an adult PTSD group or PTSD-specific gray matter findings, meeting exclusion criteria.

Abstract describes relationships between chronic pain, functional connectivity, and cortical thickness in veterans with mTBI; it does not mention a PTSD group or PTSD-related gray matter structural differences. Therefore it does not meet the criterion requiring inclusion of at least one PTSD group.

English peer-reviewed MRI study with original data in adult humans; includes PTSD group and trauma-exposed controls; uses T1-weighted MRI and voxel-based morphometry and reports gray matter reductions in hippocampus and rostral anterior cingulate associated with PTSD and duration.

No PTSD group is included; study compares veterans with and without chronic pain and examines cortical thickness related to combat exposure. Does not report gray matter differences associated with PTSD, so it fails the sample inclusion criterion.
Study investigates dissociative identity disorder (DID), not PTSD. Does not include a PTSD group, so fails the sample inclusion criterion.

Abstract does not include a PTSD group; groups are resilient, vulnerable (trauma-exposed with unspecified psychopathology), and controls. Also reports cortical thickness and surface area rather than gray-matter VBM results. Does not meet inclusion criteria for PTSD VBM studies.

Abstract describes conceptual/clinical management perspectives on blast-induced TBI and PTSD and discusses imaging potential, but provides no evidence of original MRI data, participant samples, or gray-matter/VBM findings. It appears to be a review or commentary rather than an empirical MRI study with PTSD subjects; therefore it meets exclusion criteria for non-empirical papers.

This is a systematic review of Vipassana meditation, not an empirical MRI study of PTSD. Abstract indicates no original MRI data, no PTSD sample, and no reported gray matter structural differences. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Peer-reviewed original MRI study in adult trauma-exposed veterans reporting cortical thickness (gray matter) findings related to PTSD symptom severity. The abstract does not clearly state a diagnosed PTSD group, so inclusion is warranted for full-text review to confirm presence of a PTSD group and detailed VBM/gray-matter comparisons.

Peer-reviewed PLoS One (2012) original MRI study in adult victims of urban violence with PTSD reporting decreased premotor cortex gray matter volume (structural differences). Written in English, involves adult humans with PTSD and reports gray matter alterations. No exclusion criteria met.

Peer-reviewed original MRI study in adult OEF/OIF veterans including a PTSD group; reports cortical thickness (gray matter) associations with PTSD (current and lifetime burden) and effects of comorbid mTBI. Addresses review objective of structural brain alterations in PTSD.

Original, peer-reviewed MRI study in adult humans including a group with significant PTSD symptoms (PTSD Checklist). Reports gray-matter volumetric differences (entorhinal cortex) associated with PTSD symptoms, meeting the review’s requirement for structural gray matter findings.

Abstract focuses on resting-state functional connectivity; it mentions cortical thickness hypotheses but does not clearly report gray matter structural results. Insufficient information in abstract to confirm reporting of gray-matter structural differences (e.g., VBM). Include for full-text review to determine whether gray matter structural findings associated with PTSD are reported.

Abstract reports cingulo-insular volumetric (gray matter) alterations linked to PTSD and FND symptoms in adults but does not clearly state whether a distinct PTSD diagnostic group or specific VBM methods are used. Insufficient detail to confirm all inclusion criteria from abstract alone; include for full-text review.

The study sample is pediatric (children/adolescents) with pediatric PTSD. Inclusion criteria require adult human participants. Although it reports longitudinal gray matter and functional MRI data, the population does not meet the adult-sample requirement, so exclude.

Peer-reviewed PLoS One original study measuring regional gray matter volume in trauma survivors, reports gray matter loss in recent-onset PTSD versus non-PTSD; implies MRI/voxel-based morphometry and includes a PTSD group, matching inclusion criteria.

Peer-reviewed English MRI study with original data in adult humans including PTSD groups (PTSD-only and DID-PTSD). Reports gray matter structural differences (whole-brain cortical and subcortical GM volumes) associated with PTSD, meeting inclusion criteria.

The study used MRI and MRSI in adults and reports original data, but reported metabolic (NAA) abnormalities without significant hippocampal volume reduction and did not report voxel-based morphometry or other gray-matter structural differences associated with PTSD in the abstract. Therefore it does not meet the criterion requiring reported gray matter structural differences.

Animal study in mice (CHIMERA mTBI model); not conducted in adult humans, does not include any PTSD group, and does not report MRI voxel-based gray matter structural differences. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract indicates an MRI study of cortical hypertrophy related to trauma resilience but does not explicitly state inclusion of adult PTSD patients or report voxel-based gray matter differences. Insufficient detail to confirm required PTSD group and gray-matter VBM results—include for full-text review.

Peer-reviewed original T1-weighted structural MRI study in adults including a PTSD group (83) and healthy controls; reports cortical thickness (gray matter) differences linked to PTSD symptoms and genotype. Meets inclusion criteria for gray matter structural alterations.

This is a functional MRI study of neural activity (subliminal/supraliminal processing) in PTSD; the abstract reports task-related activation, not gray matter structural differences or voxel-based morphometry, so it does not meet the structural VBM inclusion criterion.
Participants are pediatric (maltreated youth), not adult humans. Inclusion criteria require studies of adult humans with PTSD; thus this study is ineligible despite using structural MRI methods.

Study uses EEG to investigate functional connectivity in PTSD, not MRI-based structural analysis. It does not report voxel-based morphometry or gray matter structural differences, so it fails the MRI/structural outcome inclusion criteria.

The abstract addresses posttraumatic embitterment disorder (PTED) in older adults, not PTSD, and provides no evidence of MRI gray-matter (VBM) findings in a PTSD group. Thus it does not meet the review’s inclusion criteria.

Original peer-reviewed MRI study of adult PTSD patients vs controls reporting gray-matter structural differences (reduced cortical thickness in BA10, BA32, BA45 and right STG) using high-resolution structural MRI. It addresses PTSD-related structural brain alterations and reports original data; not limited to white matter. Sufficient information to include for full review.

Abstract describes prospective multimodal structural neuroimaging in adults with posttraumatic anhedonia/PTSD and implies original MRI data and structural brain markers. It does not explicitly state voxel‑based morphometry/gray matter results in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm gray matter structural differences.

Abstract reports an original, peer-reviewed structural MRI study using vertex-based morphometry identifying localized hippocampal and amygdala gray matter abnormalities in PTSD patients (adult sample implied). Meets inclusion criteria for gray matter structural differences associated with PTSD.

Peer-reviewed original MRI study in adult humans using voxel-based morphometry reporting gray matter volume differences in PTSD (right orbitofrontal cortex) among cancer survivors vs controls; meets all inclusion criteria.

Meets inclusion: English, peer-reviewed MRI study with original data in adult humans; includes a PTSD group (n=57); reports hippocampal gray-matter subfield volumetric differences associated with PTSD/trauma. Not excluded by criteria.

This article is a meta-analysis of MRI studies (reviewing 89 studies) rather than an original empirical MRI study reporting primary gray-matter VBM data from adult PTSD participants. Exclusion criteria disallow meta-analyses/reviews without original MRI data.

Study sample comprises maltreated youth/adolescents rather than adult humans required by the inclusion criteria. Additionally, the analysis uses cortical thickness/structural covariance network centrality rather than voxel-based morphometry of gray matter in adults.
The sample consists of adolescents (traumatized adolescents with and without PTSD), not adult humans as required by inclusion criteria; therefore the study does not meet the adult-sample requirement.

Abstract does not specify a group of individuals with PTSD nor report gray-matter structural (voxel-based morphometry) differences associated with PTSD. The study focuses on heterogeneous depression/anxiety/trauma sample, functional/connectivity data and data-quality metrics, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

The study uses diffusion tensor imaging to assess white matter (fronto-limbic) integrity in Gulf War veterans with PTSD. The inclusion criteria require reporting gray matter structural differences (e.g., VBM). This study reports only white matter findings, meeting an exclusion criterion.
Participants were clinically healthy adults with no psychiatric diagnosis; the study did not include any group of individuals with PTSD, which is required for inclusion in this review.

Abstract reports an original, peer-reviewed MRI morphometric study in adult PTSD patients vs controls, explicitly using voxel-based morphometry and ROI analyses to assess hippocampal (gray matter) differences; meets inclusion criteria for gray matter structural differences associated with PTSD.

Meets all inclusion criteria: English peer-reviewed MRI study of adult humans with original data; includes a PTSD group (13/28 combat veterans); uses voxel-based morphometry reporting gray-matter volume differences associated with PTSS/PTSD. No exclusion criteria are met.

Abstract examines structural brain features across six mental disorders with own-thought auditory verbal hallucinations but does not explicitly state inclusion of PTSD. Insufficient information to determine whether a PTSD group and PTSD-related gray matter VBM results are reported; include for full-text review to confirm.

Original peer-reviewed MRI study reporting associations between amygdala gray-matter volumes and PTSD symptom severity. However, abstract does not clearly state participant ages (described as 'young survivors') or explicit PTSD group vs. control; insufficient detail to confirm adult sample and group criteria. Include for full-text review to verify adult status and PTSD group/voxel-based methods.

The study prospectively assessed MRI changes in healthy soldiers with increases in PTSD-related symptoms post-exposure but does not report inclusion of a diagnosed PTSD group. Inclusion criteria require at least one group of individuals with PTSD; this is not evident from the abstract. Therefore exclude.
Study is an animal (mouse) DTI study; no adult human participants and no PTSD patient group. Does not meet inclusion requirement of MRI studies in adult humans with PTSD and gray matter VBM outcomes.

Large, peer-reviewed multisite MRI study reporting original data in adult PTSD cases and controls; reports smaller hippocampal and amygdala volumes (gray matter structural differences/subcortical volumetry) relevant to the review objective.

This study reports diffusion tensor imaging (white matter) fractional anisotropy differences in the anterior cingulum; it does not report gray matter voxel-based morphometry results. Exclusion criterion: studies reporting only white matter structural differences.

Abstract reports original, peer-reviewed voxel-based morphometry MRI data in adult humans including a PTSD patient group (n=17), and identifies gray matter volume differences associated with PTSD development; meets all inclusion criteria.

Peer-reviewed MRI study of adult coal-mine flood survivors with original data comparing 10 recent-onset PTSD vs 10 non-PTSD controls using voxel-based morphometry/ROI; reports gray matter volume/density reductions associated with PTSD.

Study sample consists of adolescents with PTSD (sexually abused adolescents), not adult humans. The review requires MRI studies among adult humans; therefore this study does not meet the adult sample inclusion criterion.

Peer-reviewed original MRI study reporting volumetric (gray matter) analysis of amygdala, hippocampus, and prefrontal cortex in PTSD participants (therapy-naive). Fits adult human PTSD sample and reports structural gray matter differences relevant to review.

Peer-reviewed MRI study in English reporting original data in adult humans (10 PTSD vs 10 trauma-exposed controls). Reports gray-matter cortical thickness (and VBM) differences associated with PTSD and correlation with symptom severity—meets all inclusion criteria.
