Study examines cortical thickness in chronic migraine patients vs controls and does not include any PTSD group or report gray-matter structural differences associated with PTSD. Not relevant to review objective.

Peer-reviewed structural MRI study in adult humans reporting gray matter volume (GMV) findings (VBM-like) correlated with intrusion symptoms and self-blame; includes PTSD and non-PTSD sexually assaulted groups. Abstract does not clearly state whether GMV differences were directly compared by PTSD diagnosis, so full-text review is needed to confirm eligibility.

Peer-reviewed MRI study of adult military personnel with combat-related PTSD (vs mTBI-only) reporting amygdala volumetric increases (gray matter structural differences). Meets all inclusion criteria (English, original MRI data, adult PTSD group, reports gray matter volume differences).

Peer-reviewed MRI study of adult humans including PTSD groups (PTSD-only and PTSD+DID) with original data; reports gray-matter structural differences (hippocampal global and subfield volumes and shape) associated with PTSD and childhood trauma. Written in English.

Abstract states the sample comprises combat trauma-exposed individuals without PTSD (subclinical); no group of individuals with PTSD is included. Fails the inclusion criterion requiring at least one PTSD group, so exclude.

Peer-reviewed MRI study in English with original data on adult humans, includes a PTSD group, and reports gray matter density differences using voxel-based morphometry associated with PTSD and trauma load; meets all inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes a genome-wide genetic overlap study linking SNPs affecting subcortical volumes to genetic risk for anxiety/PTSD, not an MRI case-control study reporting original gray-matter structural differences (e.g., VBM) in adults with PTSD. No evidence of PTSD vs control gray matter results; thus does not meet inclusion criteria.

Peer-reviewed MRI study of adult outpatients with PTSD reporting hippocampal (gray-matter) volume comparisons with trauma-exposed controls and pre/post psychotherapy volume measures; contains original data on structural brain alterations associated with PTSD. Abstract does not specify VBM but reports hippocampal gray-matter volume, which meets the review’s structural gray-matter criterion.

Study includes a group with comorbid PTSD and reports MRI-based gray matter measures (cortical thickness, amygdala volume). Abstract does not clearly state PTSD-specific gray matter contrasts, so full-text review is needed to confirm PTSD-related structural findings.

Peer-reviewed MRI study on adult humans with PTSD reporting original longitudinal data; uses voxel-based morphometry showing gray matter density changes associated with symptom recovery. Meets language, population, original data, and gray-matter VBM criteria.

Narrative/review-style article without original MRI data or reported adult human gray-matter (VBM) structural findings. Does not present empirical MRI results among PTSD patients, so it fails inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports effects of repetitive mild traumatic brain injury on cerebral blood flow and cortical thickness in Veterans; it does not include or report data from a PTSD group nor reports gray-matter structural differences associated with PTSD. Therefore it does not meet the requirement of including at least one PTSD group.

Abstract is ambiguous regarding original MRI data, inclusion of an actual PTSD patient group, and reporting of gray matter (VBM) results. It discusses PTSD among disorders but reads conceptual; insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria. Include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

This is a meta-analysis of pediatric MRI studies (not original empirical MRI data) and focuses on pediatric rather than adult samples; it therefore does not meet inclusion criteria requiring original peer-reviewed MRI studies reporting adult gray-matter structural differences.

Abstract refers to neuroimaging investigation of insular cortex in PTSD but does not specify MRI modality nor explicitly report gray-matter structural (VBM) results. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion/exclusion based on abstract alone; include for full-text review to determine whether structural gray matter differences were reported.

Abstract reports original peer-reviewed MRI structural findings (cortical thickness in anterior cingulate) relating to PTSD recovery, indicating gray matter structural differences in PTSD. Although sample age is not explicitly stated, the study context and journal imply adult human participants. Sufficient evidence from abstract to include for full-text data extraction.

English peer-reviewed MRI study with original data in adults including a PTSD group. Reports region-based morphometry (gray matter) findings: left and right anterior insula volume differences and correlations of left anterior insula volume with PTSD symptom severity, meeting the criterion of gray matter structural differences associated with PTSD.

Peer-reviewed English-language original MRI study of adult combat veterans including a PTSD group; uses voxel-based morphometry to report gray matter volume reductions in olfactory cortex associated with PTSD symptoms. Does not meet any exclusion criteria.

Abstract does not specify inclusion of a PTSD-diagnosed group or that MRI/voxel-based morphometry was used. Because key eligibility (PTSD group and gray-matter MRI results) is unclear from the abstract, include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Abstract reports original, peer-reviewed MRI-based cortical thickness analyses in adult veterans with PTSD, identifying PTSD-associated reductions in right prefrontal cortical thickness. It meets language, adult human PTSD group, and gray matter structural outcome criteria.

Abstract reports original data on drug-naïve adult PTSD patients and morphovolumetric (structural) brain changes after EMDR; however it does not explicitly state MRI/VBM or gray matter results. Insufficient detail in abstract to confirm VBM, so include for full-text review.

Study includes adult PTSD sample and healthy controls, uses MRI with cortical thickness (a gray-matter structural measure), and reports original data. Abstract does not explicitly state PTSD vs. control gray-matter differences, so full-text review is needed to confirm eligibility.

The study examines HIV+ adults with high early life stress, not a PTSD group. Although MRI gray/white matter volumes were reported, there is no group of individuals with PTSD nor are gray matter differences reported as related to PTSD. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Original peer-reviewed MRI study in adult combat veterans including PTSD+ and PTSD- groups reporting hippocampal (gray matter) volume measures. Abstract does not clearly state PTSD-related gray matter differences or VBM results; insufficient detail to rule in/exclude, so include for full-text review.

Abstract examines cortical structural traits related to susceptibility to PTSD in motor vehicle accident victims, suggesting MRI-based gray matter analysis, but does not explicitly state MRI methods, sample details, or VBM/gray matter results. Insufficient information to confirm all inclusion criteria—include for full-text review.

The abstract reports functional connectivity (graph-based nodal strength) analyses of the salience network in PTSD; it does not report gray-matter structural measures (e.g., voxel-based morphometry) or other structural MRI findings, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Study examines gray matter in borderline personality disorder (BPD) patients and uses lifetime PTSD diagnoses only as a covariate. It does not include a group of individuals with PTSD nor report voxel‑based morphometry results associated with PTSD. Therefore it does not meet the requirement of including a PTSD patient group and reporting PTSD-related GM differences.

Abstract does not explicitly report structural MRI or gray-matter (VBM) findings. Although it discusses hippocampal/VVS neuronal aberrations in PTSD, insufficient detail to confirm VBM/gray matter results. Include for full-text review to determine whether adult PTSD group and gray-matter structural differences (VBM) are reported.

Study investigates patients with dissociative seizures (DS), mesial temporal lobe sclerosis (MTS), and normal controls; no PTSD group or PTSD-related comparisons are reported, so it does not meet the requirement to include adults with PTSD and report PTSD-associated gray matter differences.

Peer-reviewed original MRI study in adult humans including a PTSD group; reports structural gray matter differences (smaller amygdala volume and reduced gray matter density in left anterior cingulate) relevant to PTSD. Methods include volumetry and reported gray matter density, meeting inclusion for gray matter structural alterations.

Study examines thalamic morphometry in veterans with mild traumatic brain injury and fatigue; abstract does not report inclusion of a PTSD group or PTSD-related gray matter differences. Does not meet requirement of studying adults with PTSD and PTSD-associated gray matter structural alterations.

Study examines effects of retrospectively reported childhood maltreatment on brain volumes in traumatized females; abstract does not report inclusion of a PTSD group or analyses of gray matter differences associated with PTSD. Therefore it does not meet the requirement of including PTSD cases.

Abstract reports a methods comparison of NeuroQuant and FreeSurfer in service members and does not mention any PTSD sample or report gray-matter structural differences associated with PTSD. This is a methodological/validation study rather than an original MRI study of PTSD, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Adult PTSD sample with MRI measures (whole brain and hippocampal volume) reported. Abstract does not specify gray-matter specific analyses or VBM nor whether structural differences are reported relative to controls; insufficient detail to exclude. Include for full-text review to determine whether gray matter/VBM results meet inclusion criteria.

Meets inclusion criteria: English, peer-reviewed MRI study of adult humans with an explicit PTSD group (coal mine gas explosion-related PTSD), reports original data, and uses voxel-based morphometry to report gray matter differences (decreased hippocampal GMV and altered hippocampus–amygdala structural covariance). No exclusion criteria are met.

This study is a meta-analysis synthesizing MRI findings rather than reporting original empirical MRI data from adult participants. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for non-empirical/meta-analytic papers without original MRI data.

Abstract indicates an original, peer-reviewed MRI study in adults with PTSD measuring rostral ACC volume. The abstract does not state whether it reports PTSD-related gray matter differences (e.g., VBM) vs controls, so inclusion is uncertain from abstract alone. Include for full-text review to determine if gray matter structural differences associated with PTSD are reported.

This study used SPECT imaging and neuropsychological outcomes following hyperbaric oxygen therapy, not MRI-based structural imaging. The abstract reports no voxel-based morphometry or gray matter structural differences associated with PTSD, so it fails inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports MRI structural differences in major depressive disorder (MDD) and borderline personality disorder (BPD); no participants with PTSD are included. Does not address PTSD-related gray matter alterations required by the review.

Sample consists of maltreated youth (children/adolescents), but the inclusion criteria require studies of adult humans. Although it is a peer-reviewed MRI study reporting gray-matter volumetric and VBM results related to PTSD, the age-group mismatch excludes it.

Abstract reports original data in adults with PTSD, examining cortical thickness (a gray-matter structural MRI measure) and its association with neurosteroid levels in PTSD with mTBI. This addresses structural brain alterations related to PTSD and meets inclusion criteria for gray matter structural differences.

Peer-reviewed MRI study of adult OEF/OIF veterans including a PTSD+mTBI group; original VBM and surface-based morphometry reporting gray matter (amygdala) volumetric reductions associated with PTSD symptoms and inhibitory-control deficits. Meets all inclusion criteria.

Peer-reviewed MRI study in English with original data on adult humans (n=220) including individuals with PTSD; uses voxel-based morphometry reporting gray matter volume associations (medial prefrontal/medial frontal) related to PTSD diagnosis and interactions with social support, meeting all inclusion criteria.

Meets inclusion criteria: English, peer-reviewed original MRI study in adult humans with a PTSD group (n=9). Reports gray matter structural differences (reduced left hippocampal and overall gray matter volumes) using SIENAX/FSL analyses. Thus relevant to structural brain alterations associated with PTSD.

Study includes a PTSD-only group but the abstract reports morphometry findings focused on mTBI; no clear PTSD-specific gray-matter structural differences are described. Inclusion requires PTSD-related gray matter results, so abstract is insufficient—full-text review needed to determine eligibility.

Peer-reviewed MRI study in adult traumatized refugees reporting original volumetric (gray matter) data for hippocampus and insula and analyzing PTSD-related differences. Volumetry constitutes gray-matter structural measures relevant to the review’s objective, so include for full-text review.

Abstract reports original, peer-reviewed MRI-based volumetric findings of reduced cerebellar (left hemisphere and vermis) gray matter volume in adults with PTSD. Adult sample, includes a PTSD group and reports gray matter structural differences relevant to the review.

Study reports original, peer-reviewed structural MRI data in adult veterans including PTSD groups. It assesses gray matter morphometry and finds reduced lateral prefrontal cortical gray matter associated with PTSD groups versus controls, meeting the review’s focus on gray matter structural differences in PTSD.

Abstract examines gray matter alterations linked to dissociation in female survivors of childhood trauma but does not report inclusion of a PTSD group or PTSD-diagnosed participants, so it fails the criterion requiring at least one PTSD group.

English peer-reviewed VBM MRI study of adult humans with PTSD (n=12) and matched non-PTSD controls; reports gray matter reductions in hippocampus, ACC, and insula using voxel-based morphometry. Meets all inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria apparent.

Peer-reviewed original MRI study in adult women with IPV-related PTSD reporting structural MRI results: childhood maltreatment severity negatively correlated with prefrontal gray matter volumes. This reports gray matter structural differences relevant to PTSD and meets inclusion criteria for structural (gray matter) findings.

Abstract reports an original, peer-reviewed MRI volumetric study comparing limbic (anterior cingulate) structure volumes in adult humans with urban violence–related PTSD versus resilient controls, indicating gray matter structural differences associated with PTSD. Meets all inclusion criteria.

Article is a narrative review on psychiatric issues in oncology (not an original empirical MRI study). Abstract does not mention PTSD groups, adult PTSD sample, or gray-matter VBM results. Meets exclusion (non-empirical/no MRI data), so exclude.

The study primarily reports white matter structural measures (FA, MPF) and PET glucose metabolism and does not present gray matter voxel-based morphometry results associated with PTSD. Although PTSD symptoms are measured, no GM structural differences linked to PTSD are reported in the abstract. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion requirement for gray matter VBM findings.

Abstract describes a narrative review (‘the author reviews recent neuroscience researches’) rather than reporting original MRI data. No adult PTSD sample, no voxel-based morphometry or gray-matter results are presented. Exclude as non-empirical.

Abstract does not state inclusion of an adult PTSD group or report VBM/gray-matter differences; it mentions hippocampal function and shape but insufficient detail. Include for full-text review to determine whether PTSD participants and gray matter structural analyses are reported.

The sample comprises women exposed to intimate partner violence without PTSD. The review requires at least one group with PTSD and reporting gray-matter structural differences associated with PTSD. The abstract explicitly states participants did not have PTSD, so it does not meet the key inclusion criterion.

Peer-reviewed 2011 MRI study reporting structural brain alterations in men with chronic PTSD; implies original data on adult humans and gray matter structural differences (voxel-based morphometry likely). Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract provides only a general statement; title mentions PTSD but gives no details on sample, MRI methods, or whether original VBM gray-matter data in adult PTSD participants are reported. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone, so include for full-text review.

Participants are adolescent boys (not adults) and the study does not include a PTSD diagnosis group; it examines delinquency and cumulative trauma in youths. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria requiring adult human samples with an included PTSD group reporting gray-matter differences.

Peer-reviewed study using structural MRI to distinguish trauma-exposed individuals with and without PTSD, reporting original data on structural neuroanatomy (likely gray matter/voxel-based analyses) in adults; meets inclusion criteria for gray matter structural differences associated with PTSD.

Study investigates gray matter changes after video-game training in healthy adult participants; it does not include any group with PTSD. Does not meet the requirement of reporting structural differences associated with PTSD, so excluded.

This is an animal (mouse) study using histology/immunohistochemistry, not a human MRI study. It does not report voxel-based morphometry or gray matter MRI findings in adult humans with PTSD, so it fails the inclusion criteria.

This study examines healthy young adults with no history of trauma or neuropsychiatric disorders and does not include any PTSD group; it therefore does not report gray-matter structural differences associated with PTSD.

This is a critical review summarizing neuroimaging literature on childhood maltreatment, not an original MRI study reporting primary data. It does not report results from an adult PTSD group or original gray-matter VBM findings. Therefore it meets exclusion criteria for non-empirical/review articles.

Peer-reviewed original MRI study in adults with PTSD and healthy controls reporting brain morphology findings (brain volume, cortical thickness) and cortical thinning—i.e., gray matter structural differences associated with PTSD—so it meets the review objective and inclusion criteria.

Study sample comprises youths rather than adults; abstract does not report an adult PTSD group nor explicit gray-matter VBM structural findings. Focus is on environmental adversity, maturation, and brain-behavior in youths, so it does not meet inclusion criteria requiring adult PTSD MRI VBM data.

Peer-reviewed MRI study in adult humans with PTSD; original data from monozygotic twin design reporting gray matter volume reductions (pregenual anterior cingulate) associated with PTSD, matching inclusion criteria.

Peer-reviewed MRI study of adult breast cancer survivors including a PTSD group (original data). Reports volumetric (gray matter) measurements of hippocampus and amygdala and finds an association between PTSD intrusion scores and hippocampal volume, meeting the review objective of structural gray matter alterations related to PTSD.
Study examines dissociative identity disorder, not PTSD; no PTSD group reported in abstract. Does not meet inclusion criterion requiring at least one PTSD group.

Abstract reports reduced gray matter volumes (ACC and orbitofrontal) in child abuse-related complex PTSD, indicating a structural brain (volumetric) study in humans with PTSD. Although the abstract does not explicitly state MRI modality, voxel-based morphometry, or participant ages, it clearly addresses gray matter volume differences in a PTSD group. Insufficient methodological detail in the abstract to confirm adults and VBM, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

The study examines postpartum mothers and associations of personal growth initiative with gray matter volume; it does not include any participants with PTSD nor report gray matter differences associated with PTSD. Therefore it does not meet the requirement of having a PTSD group.

This is a systematic review of pediatric (children/adolescents) sMRI findings, not an original MRI study in adult humans. It does not report original gray-matter structural data in adult PTSD samples, thus fails inclusion criteria on study type and sample.

Abstract reports original MRI volumetric measurements of hippocampal formation and amygdaloidal complex asymmetry in PTSD patients (human sample) and describes gray-matter structural differences. Although age group and specific VBM methodology are not stated, the study meets the review objective and provides insufficient detail to exclude, so include for full-text review.

Abstract includes sMRI grey-matter volume as part of a multimodal analysis linked to trauma-related symptom measures including posttraumatic stress, but does not explicitly state a PTSD diagnostic group or report VBM/gray matter comparisons associated with PTSD. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone—include for full-text review.

Study reports original MRI data in adult humans with acute PTSD, uses voxel-based morphometry and volumetric analyses of the anterior cingulate cortex (gray matter structural differences), published in English in a peer-reviewed journal; meets inclusion criteria.

Study examines trauma-exposed healthy individuals without PTSD compared to controls; no group of individuals with PTSD is included, so it does not meet the requirement of including at least one PTSD group.

Sample consists of adolescents (not adults) and the study examines unresolved-disorganized attachment associations with hippocampal volume rather than reporting gray-matter structural differences specifically linked to PTSD in an adult PTSD group (no clear adult PTSD group comparison or VBM reported). Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Adult, peer-reviewed MRI study with original data comparing drug-naïve PTSD patients to healthy controls; reports significant reductions in left and right hippocampal volumes and overall gray matter volume associated with PTSD, meeting the review’s focus on gray matter structural differences.

Study examines hippocampal volume in cancer survivors with distressing cancer-related recollections; it does not include a PTSD group. The meta-analysis requires at least one group of individuals with PTSD, so the study is not eligible.

Abstract/title suggest brain structural abnormalities but provides no details about MRI methods, voxel-based morphometry, or explicit PTSD group. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to determine whether adult PTSD group and gray-matter MRI results are reported.

Abstract describes adult survivors of childhood abuse with dissociative disorders (DA/DID) and does not indicate inclusion of a PTSD patient group or report gray-matter structural differences associated with PTSD. Fails the requirement that at least one PTSD group be included and that results report PTSD-related gray matter differences.

MRI study with adult PTSD patients reporting original data on gray-matter structure (amygdala volumes) and significant volumetric change following therapy. Abstract contains sufficient evidence of structural gray-matter measures; include for full-text to confirm VBM methods and other inclusion details.

Non-human (primate) study; does not involve adult human participants or a PTSD patient group, and does not report PTSD-associated gray matter (VBM) findings. Fails sample and outcome inclusion criteria.

Title/abstract indicate an original voxel-based morphometry MRI study of adult rape victims with PTSD reporting grey matter differences. Meets language, peer-reviewed MRI, adult PTSD group, and gray matter VBM criteria.

Study investigates cognitive training effects in chronic TBI patients (depressed vs non-depressed). It does not include a PTSD diagnostic group and does not report gray-matter structural differences associated with PTSD. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring at least one PTSD group.

The study examines pediatric (child/adolescent) maltreatment-related PTSD, whereas inclusion requires adult human samples. Additionally, it reports cerebellar volumetry in a pediatric sample rather than adult voxel-based gray matter differences. Thus it does not meet the adult-sample criterion.

Meets inclusion: peer-reviewed NeuroImage article in English reporting original MRI data in adult humans including a PTSD group (8 PTSD, 13 controls). Uses voxel-based morphometry to report anterior cingulate gray matter volume differences associated with PTSD. No exclusion criteria met.

The sample comprises trauma-exposed individuals but does not report a group diagnosed with PTSD. Inclusion requires at least one PTSD group; therefore the study does not meet the review’s core inclusion criterion.

Not an MRI structural study of humans. Abstract reports molecular/immunology experiments in mice and peripheral biomarkers; although it mentions volumetric brain changes in PTSD patients, it does not report original MRI/voxel-based morphometry data or gray-matter structural comparisons among adults.

Peer-reviewed structural MRI study with original data in adult (male) PTSD patients. Includes a PTSD group and reports gray matter volume differences (hippocampus, right IFG, thalamus) between credible PTSD and malingerers, meeting the review objective of structural gray matter alterations in PTSD.

Study involves healthy adolescents (n=63) and examines maternal affiliation—no PTSD group, not adult sample, and does not report PTSD-related gray matter differences. Does not meet sample or outcome inclusion criteria.

Peer-reviewed structural MRI study in adults with PTSD groups reporting original data. Reports gray-matter regional volumetric differences (hippocampus, ACC, insula, etc.) measured with FreeSurfer, not limited to white matter. Although not VBM, it meets the review’s gray-matter structural criteria.
Participants are pediatric (ages 7–14). Inclusion criteria require adult human samples; therefore the study does not meet the sample-age criterion despite reporting gray matter differences via MRI.

Abstract reports cortical thickness (gray matter measure) in combat veterans and appears to report original data, but does not explicitly state that a PTSD group was included. Because it is unclear whether participants with PTSD are present yet MRI gray-matter outcomes are studied, include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Peer-reviewed MRI study in adults reporting original data on hippocampus and amygdala volumes. Includes a group of BPD patients with comorbid PTSD and examines volume reductions related to PTSD, i.e., gray matter structural differences. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria for PTSD-related gray matter structural alterations.

Adult MRI study reports reduced corpus callosum (mid-sagittal area and subregions), i.e., white matter differences. The abstract does not report gray matter structural differences or VBM results. Meets exclusion criterion: studies only reporting white matter structural differences.

Study examines hippocampal volume in women with major depressive disorder and childhood abuse; does not include any group with PTSD nor report PTSD-related gray matter differences, so it does not meet the requirement of including PTSD patients.

Original peer-reviewed MRI study of adult humans including 25 drug-naive PTSD patients and 25 controls; uses voxel-based morphometry (and SIENAX) to report cortical gray matter volume decreases associated with PTSD. Meets all inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria are met.

MRI study of adult PTSD patients reports original volumetric/structural measurements of the hippocampal formation showing reduced hippocampal dimensions (gray-matter structure). Meets MRI, adult PTSD, and gray matter structural difference criteria.

Peer-reviewed PNAS MRI study on adult humans reporting original data. Includes a PTSD group (9) and trauma-exposed controls (16). Uses voxel-based morphometry and reports gray-matter volume reductions in the left anterior cingulate associated with PTSD, meeting inclusion criteria.

The study uses diffusion tensor imaging and reports white-matter (corpus callosum) fractional anisotropy findings and correlations with PTSD; it does not report gray-matter structural differences (e.g., VBM). It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for studies only reporting white matter structural differences.

Study examined BDNF polymorphism effects on gray matter in healthy volunteers and did not include any PTSD patient group; therefore it does not meet the requirement of including at least one PTSD group reporting gray matter differences.

Abstract reports original, peer-reviewed structural MRI results in adult police officers relating PTSD symptom scores to regional gray matter volumes. However it does not state whether a diagnosed PTSD group was included nor whether VBM was used, so full-text review is needed to confirm eligibility.

Abstract reports original VBM MRI data comparing PTSD patients and controls and describes gray matter density/volume differences — matches review objective. Age group and publication language not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm adult sample and English-language peer-reviewed publication.

This is a preclinical study in adolescent rats examining diet and stress; it is not an MRI study of adult human PTSD patients and does not report voxel-based gray matter differences. Fails the ‘adult humans with PTSD’ and ‘human MRI gray matter’ inclusion criteria.

The abstract describes regional cerebral blood flow/brain perfusion correlations (functional perfusion), not structural MRI gray matter analyses or VBM. Does not report gray matter structural differences associated with PTSD, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Peer-reviewed original MRI study in English with adult PTSD group and healthy controls. Reports cortical gray matter (dACC) thickness measured with FreeSurfer and a significant association between dACC thickness and alexithymia within the PTSD group. Although the abstract does not explicitly state between-group gray matter differences, it clearly reports gray matter structural findings related to PTSD, so include for full-text review.
Sample comprises pediatric participants (ages 7–14). Inclusion criteria require adult human samples; thus study does not meet the adult-sample requirement.

This is a meta-analysis (secondary summary) rather than an original empirical MRI study reporting primary data. It does not report voxel-based gray matter structural results from adult PTSD participants, so it fails inclusion criteria.

Original, peer-reviewed study in English with adult combat-related PTSD participants; uses structural MRI to measure cortical thickness and reports thinner right superior temporal gyrus (gray matter) associated with PTSD. Meets inclusion criteria for gray matter structural differences.
Study sample comprises maltreated children and adolescents with PTSD, not adult humans; therefore it fails the inclusion criterion requiring adult participants.
Animal study using a rat PTSD model; not an adult human sample and does not report MRI or voxel-based morphometry of gray matter. Fails key inclusion criteria.

The study measures neurosteroid levels in the medial orbital frontal cortex (biochemical assays) and does not report MRI-based gray matter structural analyses (e.g., voxel-based morphometry). It therefore does not meet the criterion of reporting gray matter structural differences associated with PTSD.

The study examines structural brain differences in adults with generalized social phobia, not PTSD. Inclusion requires at least one PTSD group; this abstract does not indicate any PTSD participants, so it is not eligible for a PTSD-focused meta-analysis.

Study reports MRI subcortical shape measures in mild traumatic brain injury patients and subjective symptoms; abstract does not mention any PTSD sample or report gray-matter structural differences associated with PTSD. Does not meet requirement of including an adult PTSD group.

Study investigates respiratory physiology in panic disorder using ambulatory monitoring; it is not an MRI study, does not involve PTSD patients, and reports no gray matter structural MRI data. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Study compares major depressive disorder and borderline personality disorder; no PTSD group is included. The review requires at least one PTSD patient group reporting gray matter structural differences, which is not met by this study.

This is a proton magnetic resonance spectroscopy (1H-MRS) study reporting metabolite ratios (NAA/Cr, Cho/Cr, mI/Cr) rather than structural gray matter measures (e.g., voxel-based morphometry). It does not report gray matter structural differences associated with PTSD, so it does not meet the review’s structural MRI inclusion criterion.

Abstract does not report gray-matter structural differences associated with PTSD nor a PTSD vs control group. Study examines child abuse interaction with hippocampal and corpus callosum volumes on psychophysiological responses; CC is white matter and analyses are volumetric rather than VBM. Insufficient evidence that it reports gray-matter PTSD-related structural differences.

This study reports electrophysiological (slow-wave) findings in schizophrenia and other psychiatric disorders (EEG/MEG), not MRI-based structural analyses. The abstract does not mention adult PTSD samples or voxel-based morphometry/gray matter structural differences. Does not meet inclusion criteria for MRI VBM studies of PTSD.

This is a PET functional imaging study measuring regional cerebral blood flow during symptom provocation, not a structural MRI study reporting gray matter differences (e.g., VBM). It does not report original structural gray matter alterations, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Methods/reliability study of a manual caudate tracing protocol; no participants with PTSD, no voxel-based morphometry or gray-matter differences reported related to PTSD. Does not address review objective.

Original peer-reviewed MRI study (surface-based morphometry) on adult humans including a PTSD group; reports gray matter cortical thickness differences (hippocampus, cingulate, frontal, parietal regions) associated with PTSD symptom severity. Meets inclusion criteria.
Animal (rodent) study using microPET and histology; not a human MRI study and does not report gray-matter structural MRI/VBM differences in adult PTSD patients. Exclude.

Peer-reviewed original MRI volumetric study in adult humans including a PTSD group; reports reduced olfactory bulb volumes (gray matter structural differences) associated with lifetime PTSD. Meets language, population, and structural gray matter outcome criteria.

The study investigates gray matter differences in adults with MDD and childhood trauma versus controls using VBM, but does not include any participants with PTSD. The review requires at least one PTSD group, so this study is excluded.

Study examines trait anxiety in healthy adults and reports cortical thickness/ subcortical volume correlations; it does not include any group of individuals with PTSD nor report PTSD-associated gray matter differences. Therefore it does not meet the criterion requiring at least one PTSD group.
Abstract reports data from previously maltreated but healthy adults, not a group of individuals with PTSD. Inclusion requires at least one PTSD group; criterion not met. Therefore excluded.

Not relevant to review objective: this is a pharmacological microsampling method study concerning antidepressant blood/oral-fluid monitoring. It does not involve MRI, PTSD patient groups, or gray-matter structural brain measures.

The study reports hippocampal volumes in first-episode schizophrenia patients and healthy controls; no PTSD group is included. The review requires studies with at least one PTSD group reporting gray-matter structural differences, so this study does not meet inclusion criteria.

The study examines brain structural alterations in patients with auditory verbal hallucinations across different mental disorders and does not mention PTSD or include a PTSD patient group. It therefore does not report gray matter differences associated with PTSD as required for inclusion.

Title indicates MRI/MRS study of hippocampal structural abnormalities in fire victims with recent-onset PTSD, but the abstract is brief and does not specify adult sample, original data details, or whether gray matter VBM/GM differences were reported. Insufficient methodological detail in abstract — include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

This is an animal (dPAG) pharmacology study in non-human subjects investigating CRF receptor effects on defensive behavior. It does not involve adult human participants, PET/MRI, or report gray-matter structural MRI findings in PTSD. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

The study examined only healthy, non-clinical participants and did not include any group with PTSD. The review requires at least one PTSD group reporting gray matter differences; thus it does not meet the inclusion sample criterion.

Study examines functional neurological disorder (FND), not PTSD; no PTSD participant group or PTSD-related structural gray matter findings reported. Therefore it does not meet the requirement of including adults with PTSD.

Peer-reviewed MRI study of adult (male veteran) humans with PTSD vs controls reporting original data and gray-matter structural differences (reduced cortical thickness in frontal and temporal gyri). Meets inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI functional activation study (BOLD) of memory in Complex PTSD; it does not report gray matter structural differences or voxel-based morphometry results. Post-hoc volumetric comparisons found no significant anatomical differences, so the abstract does not provide structural gray-matter findings required for inclusion.

Study is an animal (rodent) experiment investigating pharmacologic effects on prefrontal cortex dendritic spines; not an MRI study of adult humans, does not include PTSD patients, and does not report gray matter VBM results.

Abstract describes a protocol/methods paper integrating imaging approaches for PTSD and does not report original MRI results or any gray-matter (e.g., VBM) findings. Appears non-empirical/methods-only, so does not meet inclusion criteria requiring original MRI data reporting gray matter structural differences.

Study examines cancer survivors with intrusive recollections, not a group of individuals diagnosed with PTSD. Although it reports amygdala volumetry, it does not report gray-matter structural differences associated with PTSD or include a PTSD sample, so it fails the sample criterion.
Study examines acute stress disorder (ASD) patients, not PTSD. Inclusion requires at least one PTSD group; abstract reports no PTSD sample. Therefore it does not meet the review’s sample criterion.

Abstract does not report any PTSD group or PTSD-related findings; it focuses on reactive attachment disorder (RAD) and childhood maltreatment, not adult PTSD. No evidence the study reports gray matter differences associated with PTSD. Exclude.

Study examines children/adolescents with reactive attachment disorder using fMRI reward processing; does not include adult humans or a PTSD group and reports functional activity (fMRI) rather than gray-matter structural (VBM) differences.

Study involves healthy adult participants randomized to mindfulness vs active control; no group with PTSD is included. Inclusion criterion requires at least one PTSD group reporting gray-matter structural differences; thus excluded.

Animal (mouse) study; no adult human participants or PTSD patient group. Uses diffusion tensor imaging in mice rather than human MRI voxel-based gray matter analyses, so does not meet criteria for studies reporting gray matter structural differences in adult PTSD.

Abstract reports longitudinal neuroimaging of trauma survivors and investigation of brain correlates of recovery from PTSD but does not explicitly state that gray matter structural differences (e.g., VBM) are reported or provide sufficient methodological detail. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria on abstract alone — include for full-text review.

The study examines generalized anxiety disorder (GAD), not PTSD, and includes no PTSD group. It uses proton MRSI to report metabolite concentrations in centrum semiovale (white matter) rather than gray-matter structural (VBM) differences. Thus it does not meet the review's PTSD and gray-matter structural inclusion criteria.

Abstract does not include any PTSD patient group or mention PTSD; study examines sensitivity to negative life events (adolescents) and rumination with VBM but not PTSD. Does not meet sample criterion requiring at least one PTSD group.

Original peer-reviewed MRI study of adult chronic PTSD patients reporting bilateral amygdala volumetry (gray matter structural differences). Fits review objective of structural brain alterations associated with PTSD.

Not an MRI or neuroimaging study and does not involve humans with PTSD. It reports engineering/blast mitigation experiments on body armor and hydraulic tubing, with no voxel-based morphometry or gray matter results. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Study used single-voxel MRS and ROI hippocampal volumetry in former POWs with/without PTSD, not voxel-based morphometry or whole-brain gray matter analyses as specified. Abstract does not report VBM or broader gray-matter structural differences associated with PTSD, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion.

fulltext_screening_results.reason: The study uses tensor-based morphometry (TBM) to assess whole-brain structural differences, not voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume or concentration as required. Although it includes an adult PTSD group and a healthy control group (satisfying sample criteria) and reports whole-brain TBM results, the inclusion criteria specifically mandate VBM methods. TBM is a different morphometric technique and therefore falls under the exclusion criterion for studies using non-voxel-based morphometry methods. Consequently, the study does not meet the required imaging-method inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

Although the study includes adult PTSD and trauma-exposed control soldier groups, it does not perform voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume/concentration. Methods report surface-based cortical thickness (CIVET vertex- and lobe-based analyses) and region segmentation/volumetry via MAGeT (subcortical and cerebellar ROIs). No whole-brain VBM results or coordinate-based between-group VBM contrasts are reported. Therefore it fails the required inclusion criterion of reporting at least one whole-brain VBM result comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls.

This study used whole-brain voxel-based morphometry (VBM-DARTEL) of gray matter volume obtained with MRI and reports whole-brain between-group contrasts (PTSD vs healthy controls and PTSD vs other patient groups) with corrected cluster-level results and peak coordinates. The sample includes an adult PTSD group (Wenchuan earthquake survivors) and a trauma-unexposed healthy control group, satisfying the requirement of a PTSD group plus at least one comparison group (trauma-unexposed controls). Results are whole-brain (FWE-corrected) and coordinate-based findings are described, not limited to ROIs. The study is not a treatment-only or ROI-only paper and participants are adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

The study does not use whole-brain voxel-based morphometry (VBM). It reports manual region-of-interest segmentation of the habenula (ROI volumetry) rather than VBM analyses and provides no whole-brain, coordinate-based between-group contrasts. Additionally, the comparison groups are PTSD patients vs. trauma-unexposed healthy controls only (no trauma-exposed non-PTSD group). Therefore it fails the primary inclusion criteria requiring MRI VBM measures and whole-brain voxelwise results comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls.

This study reports whole-brain voxel-based morphometry (VBM) using MRI and compares a chronic PTSD group (n=12) to a trauma-exposed control group (miners without PTSD, n=14). Adults only (males 18–49) were included. The paper presents whole-brain VBM results (between-group ANOVAs and post-hoc two-sample t-tests with Alphasim correction) describing regional gray matter volume differences for PTSD vs. trauma-exposed controls and PTSD vs. symptoms-improved survivors. It is not an ROI-only study, does not focus solely on treatment/longitudinal effects, and provides between-group voxel-based comparisons relevant to the review objective. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria (VBM whole-brain results, PTSD group plus trauma-exposed comparison, adult sample) and does not violate exclusion criteria.

Although the study acquired and preprocessed GMV maps via a VBM pipeline and included adult PTSD, trauma-exposed non-PTSD (TEC), and non-traumatized healthy control groups, it does not report whole-brain, coordinate-based voxel-wise VBM group-comparison results (mass-univariate statistical contrasts) comparing PTSD to TEC or PTSD to HC. The manuscript uses GMV maps as features for multivariate SVM classification and presents SVM discrimination-weight maps (thresholded weights) rather than voxel-wise VBM statistical comparisons with coordinates/p-values. Therefore it fails the requirement to report at least one whole-brain VBM between-group result; it reports multivariate classification/discrimination maps only, which do not satisfy the review’s inclusion criterion for VBM group-comparison results.

This is a longitudinal treatment study of 20 male soldiers with combat-related PTSD randomized to therapy vs waiting-list; no trauma-exposed non-PTSD or trauma-unexposed healthy control group is included. Although MRI VBM preprocessing was used, the reported analyses focus on region-of-interest (hippocampus and amygdala) rather than whole-brain VBM comparisons, and the primary outcomes are treatment/longitudinal effects. The review requires at least one whole-brain VBM between-group contrast comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed non-PTSD or trauma-unexposed controls; this study does not provide such coordinate-based whole-brain results and is thus ineligible.

The study uses automated subcortical volumetry (FreeSurfer segmentation) and reports region-based volumes and GWAS associations, not voxel-based morphometry (VBM). It does not present whole-brain voxel-wise VBM results or coordinate-based between-group contrasts (PTSD vs controls). Therefore it fails the primary inclusion criterion requiring MRI VBM (whole-brain voxel-wise) results reported with coordinate-based findings.

Although the study used whole-brain VBM of gray matter and included participants with PTSD and trauma-exposed non-PTSD veterans, it did not report any between-group voxelwise contrasts comparing individuals with PTSD to trauma-exposed non-PTSD or trauma-unexposed controls. The analyses focused on within-subject voxelwise regressions relating symptom severity (CAPS) and other continuous measures to gray matter volume. The review requires at least one coordinate-based whole-brain between-group VBM contrast (PTSD vs trauma-exposed or controls). Therefore the study does not meet the inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

This study does not meet the VBM requirement. Although it uses structural MRI in adult PTSD and control groups (current PTSD, remitted PTSD, trauma-exposed controls), analyses are based on FreeSurfer-derived cortical thickness and group-level structural covariance/graph-theory centrality measures, not voxel-based morphometry of gray matter volume/concentration. The paper does not report whole-brain voxel-wise VBM results or coordinate-based contrasts comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls. Therefore it fails the primary inclusion criterion that the study measure and report VBM results (whole-brain, coordinate-based) and must be excluded.

This study does not meet the imaging modality requirement and lacks the required comparison groups. It uses diffusion MRI (free-water imaging) reporting fractional anisotropy and mean diffusivity (microstructural dMRI), not voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume or concentration. Additionally, the sample includes only individuals with current PTSD (subdivided into PTSD-only and PTSD+TBI); there is no trauma-exposed non-PTSD group nor a trauma-unexposed healthy control group, and no whole-brain VBM coordinate-based contrasts comparing PTSD to those comparison groups. Therefore it fails the VBM measurement and sample/comparator inclusion criteria.

Study uses voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume with MRI; includes an adult PTSD group (n=91) and an unexposed healthy control group (n=201); reports whole-brain VBM comparisons (PTSD vs HC included within diagnosis-specific contrasts and in the transdiagnostic inclusive mask) with coordinate-based results (bilateral putamen clusters) surviving whole-brain FWE correction. Not ROI-only, not longitudinal/treatment only, and includes required between-group contrast (PTSD vs trauma-unexposed controls). Therefore meets all inclusion criteria.

This study does not meet the core imaging-method inclusion criteria. It uses atlas-based regional volumetry (multi-atlas segmentation of hippocampus and amygdala; regional ROI volumes) rather than voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter concentration/volume. No whole-brain voxelwise VBM analyses or coordinate-based between-group VBM results are reported; comparisons are limited to ROI median volumes and non-significant group differences. Additionally, PTSD status is based on a low PCL-S threshold and very small case numbers, but the decisive exclusion is the absence of VBM/whole-brain coordinate results required by the review. Therefore it must be excluded.

Although the study uses whole-brain VBM and includes a PTSD subgroup (BPD+PTSD), it does not report a whole-brain VBM contrast comparing individuals with PTSD to trauma-exposed individuals without PTSD or to trauma-unexposed healthy controls. The reported between-group whole-brain comparison is BPD+PTSD vs BPD-PTSD (both groups have BPD), and it is unclear whether the BPD-PTSD group is trauma-exposed. There is no clear coordinate-based PTSD vs healthy control (or PTSD vs trauma-exposed non-PTSD) contrast in the paper. Thus it fails the requirement to report at least one whole-brain between-group VBM contrast comparing PTSD cases to an acceptable comparison group.

This study does not meet the VBM or whole-brain voxel-based morphometry inclusion criteria. It reports hippocampal subfield volumes derived from FreeSurfer automated segmentation (ROI-based volumetry of 10 hippocampal subfields) rather than voxel-wise, whole-brain VBM analyses, and no coordinate-based whole-brain between-group VBM results are reported. Although it includes adult PTSD and comparison participants (combat-exposed veterans), the imaging method and reported outcomes are region-of-interest volumetric analyses, violating the requirement for VBM coordinate-based whole-brain results. Therefore it must be excluded.

Although the study uses MRI-based voxel-based morphometry and includes both a PTSD group and a trauma-exposed non-PTSD comparison group (adult sample), the reported VBM analyses are correlational (GMV correlated with a Sleep Disturbances Score) across the whole sample and within each group. The full text does not present coordinate-based, whole-brain VBM results from a between-group contrast directly comparing PTSD versus trauma-exposed controls (or versus trauma-unexposed controls). Because the review’s inclusion criteria require at least one whole-brain VBM between-group comparison (with coordinate results), this study does not meet that criterion and must be excluded.

The study does not meet the VBM requirement: it reports surface-based cortical thickness analyses using FreeSurfer (vertex-wise cortical thickness), not voxel-based morphometry of gray matter volume or concentration. It also does not present whole-brain, coordinate-based VBM contrasts comparing PTSD cases to trauma-exposed non-PTSD or trauma-unexposed controls; analyses are correlational/mediation within a trauma-exposed veteran sample (PTSD symptom severity), not between-group VBM comparisons. Therefore it fails the primary inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it used voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter (SPM5 with DARTEL, modulated GM images) from T1 MRI; includes an adult PTSD group (n=16 after exclusions) and a trauma-exposed control group without PTSD (n=16); and reports whole-brain VBM between-group results (significant decreased gray matter volume in ventral premotor cortex and pregenual anterior cingulate in PTSD vs. trauma-exposed controls, p<0.05 FDR-corrected, with clusters described and shown in figures). Although ROI analyses for hippocampus/amygdala were also performed, whole-brain voxelwise results are reported, so the study is not ROI-only. Sample is adult and the paper reports between-group coordinate/cluster results. Limitations (small sample, no non-traumatized control group) do not preclude inclusion per the review criteria. Therefore include.

The study does not use voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume/concentration. It uses surface-based cortical thickness measures (FreeSurfer vertex-wise analyses) rather than VBM and does not report whole-brain VBM coordinate-based results. Although it includes an adult PTSD group and a trauma-exposed control group, it fails to meet the primary inclusion criterion requiring VBM methodology and coordinate-based whole-brain VBM comparisons. Therefore it must be excluded.

The study uses whole-brain voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume (SPM8/DARTEL) and reports cluster-corrected, FWE whole-brain results. Participant groups include recent-onset PTSD (n=10), trauma-exposed non-PTSD (n=10), and trauma-unexposed healthy controls (n=20). The paper reports between-group whole-brain contrasts (PTSD vs. normal controls: decreased left ACC; non-PTSD vs. normal controls: decreased pallidum and pulvinar) with corrected statistics, meeting the requirement for whole-brain, coordinate-based VBM comparisons. Participants are adults and analyses are not ROI-only, longitudinal-only, or treatment-only. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This study does not meet inclusion criteria. It used surface-based cortical thickness analysis (FreeSurfer) and ROI/subcortical volume analyses rather than voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume/concentration. The sample contains trauma-exposed (TE) participants and healthy controls but no identified PTSD group (only two TE participants exceeded an IES-R cutoff; no PTSD diagnosis group was included). The paper therefore provides no whole-brain VBM voxel-based between-group contrasts (PTSD vs TE or PTSD vs HC) or coordinate-based VBM results required by the review. Thus it must be excluded.

The study does not meet the key imaging inclusion criterion. It uses surface-based morphometry (cortical thickness estimation via CAT12 and Desikan–Killiany atlas) rather than voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume or concentration, and it does not report whole‑brain VBM coordinate-based between-group contrasts comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls. Although adult PTSD and healthy groups are included, the absence of VBM whole-brain results (coordinate tables/figures) means it fails the primary inclusion criterion for this meta-analysis.

The study does not use voxel-based morphometry (VBM). It reports vertex-wise shape analyses of the hippocampus and amygdala using FSL FIRST (subcortical surface/ROI-based shape measures), not whole-brain VBM gray-matter volume or concentration. No whole-brain coordinate-based VBM results comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls are reported. Therefore it fails the primary imaging-method and whole-brain VBM result inclusion criteria.

The study does not use voxel-based morphometry (VBM) whole-brain analyses. It reports ROI/segmentation-based volumetry of amygdala nuclei derived from FreeSurfer rather than VBM gray-matter concentration/volume with coordinate-based whole-brain contrasts. The primary analyses are continuous symptom-volume associations within trauma survivors (and some group ANCOVAs of total amygdala volume), not whole-brain VBM contrasts comparing PTSD versus trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls with reported coordinates. Therefore it fails the required imaging-method and whole-brain/coordinate-based result inclusion criteria.

This study reports manual/automated volumetric ROI analyses (segmentation of amygdala, hippocampus, prefrontal cortex) rather than voxel-based morphometry (VBM). No whole-brain VBM analysis or coordinate-based between-group VBM results are reported (only ROI volumes and summary statistics). Therefore it fails the inclusion criteria requiring MRI VBM (whole-brain voxel-wise) results and coordinate-based contrasts comparing PTSD to controls. Other criteria (adult PTSD and comparison group) are met, but the lack of VBM/whole-brain coordinate results mandates exclusion.

Although the study includes an adult PTSD group and a trauma-exposed non-PTSD comparison group and reports whole-brain structural comparisons, its primary neuroimaging outcome is cortical thickness estimated via an improved Laplacian surface/voxel-based thickness method, not voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume or concentration. While VBM-DARTEL was used for preprocessing/segmentation, no VBM voxel-wise gray matter volume/concentration results or coordinate-based VBM contrasts are reported. This therefore fails the inclusion criterion requiring measurement and reporting of VBM gray matter volume/concentration results. The study thus meets the exclusion criterion for using non-VBM morphometric methods (cortical thickness only).

This adult (ages 19–37) MRI study used voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume and reports whole-brain VBM results (FDR-corrected cluster-level; peak MNI coordinates and cluster size) showing decreased lingual gyrus GMV associated with self-blame and differences between PTSD and non-PTSD subgroups. The sample includes trauma-exposed women with PTSD (n≈25 above PCL-5 cutoff) and trauma-exposed non-PTSD subgroup as well as non-exposed controls, and the paper reports between-group comparisons (PTSD vs non-PTSD and NEC). Results are whole-brain, coordinate-based, and adults only. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, non-adult sample, or absence of PTSD group) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study does not meet the primary imaging-method inclusion criterion: it uses cortical-thickness analysis (FreeSurfer) and automated volumetry, not voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume/concentration, and it provides no whole-brain VBM coordinate-based results. Secondary sampling criterion is also not satisfied for the meta-analysis objective: the PTSD cases are comorbid with BPD (BPD+PTSD), not a PTSD-only group, and contrasts are between BPD subgroups and controls rather than between PTSD-only vs trauma-exposed non-PTSD or trauma-unexposed controls. Therefore it fails to provide the required whole-brain VBM case-control contrasts comparing PTSD to appropriate comparison groups. All other exclusion criteria (adult sample) are met, but the two primary inclusion requirements are not, so the study must be excluded.

This study does not use voxel-based morphometry (VBM); it uses automated ROI volumetry (FreeSurfer segmentation of hippocampus and amygdala) rather than whole-brain VBM analyses. No whole-brain, coordinate-based VBM results comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed non-PTSD or trauma-unexposed controls are reported. Although a PTSD group is included, the imaging method and reported outcomes do not meet the meta-analysis requirement for VBM whole-brain voxelwise results; therefore it must be excluded.

This study used voxel-based morphometry (VBM) on MRI to compare gray-matter density between a PTSD group (n=12) and a trauma-exposed non-PTSD comparison group (n=12). Whole-brain VBM results are reported, including Talairach coordinates and T-scores for reduced gray matter in PTSD (e.g., bilateral insula, left medial frontal gyrus), satisfying the requirement for coordinate-based, whole-brain between-group contrasts. Participants are adults and the study is not ROI-only, treatment-only, longitudinal-only, or limited to non-adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Although the study includes adult PTSD, trauma-exposed (TC), and trauma-unexposed healthy control (HC) groups, it does NOT report whole-brain voxel-based morphometry (VBM) results. Gray-matter analyses were performed using region-based morphometry (RBM) on 14 predefined ROIs (Neuromorphometrics atlas) rather than a whole-brain VBM/voxelwise analysis with coordinate-based results. The inclusion criteria require at least one whole-brain VBM result comparing PTSD to TC or HC; the present paper only reports ROI-based regional volumes and ROI statistics. Therefore it fails the ‘whole-brain VBM’ inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

This study does not use voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume or concentration. Morphometry analyses are cortical thickness measures derived from FreeSurfer and ROI-based thickness analyses, not whole-brain VBM. The paper reports ROI-to-ROI functional connectivity (resting-state fMRI) and cortical thickness associations, without coordinate-based whole-brain VBM contrasts comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls. Therefore it fails the primary inclusion criterion requiring VBM voxel-wise results and whole-brain between-group VBM contrasts.

Although the study uses VBM of gray matter volume on adult PTSD patients and includes a comparison group of non‑traumatized healthy controls, the voxel-wise analyses were restricted to a combined hippocampus/amygdala mask (ROI-based analysis) rather than reporting whole‑brain VBM results. The review’s inclusion criteria require at least one whole‑brain voxel‑based morphometry contrast comparing PTSD to trauma‑exposed or trauma‑unexposed controls. Because the reported results are ROI‑restricted (hippocampus/amygdala mask) and thus meet the exclusion criterion for ROI‑only analyses, the study should be excluded.

The study reports whole-brain voxel-based morphometry (FSL-VBM) analyses comparing an adult group with PTSD (comorbid PTSD/mTBI; N=21) to a trauma-exposed deployed control group without PTSD or mTBI (N=16). Whole-brain VBM results (TFCE-corrected, 5000 permutations) showing reduced bilateral anterior amygdala volume in the PTSD/mTBI group are described, and surface-based morphometry was used to corroborate VBM findings. The sample is adult (ages 18–45). Although the PTSD group is comorbid with mTBI, inclusion criteria required at least one PTSD group and at least one comparison group (met here), and comorbidity is not an exclusion in the stated criteria. The paper provides whole-brain VBM between-group results and links them to behavioral measures, satisfying the meta-analysis inclusion criteria.

This study used voxel-based morphometry (SPM12/CAT12) on high-resolution T1 MRI and reports whole-brain, voxel-wise results comparing adults with PTSD (n=57) to trauma-exposed non-PTSD adults (n=163). Whole-brain GM volume differences (e.g., reduced medial and middle frontal gyri in PTSD) are reported with coordinates/figures and corrected/uncorrected thresholds. Sample consists of adults, not treatment or longitudinal-only, and analyses are whole-brain rather than ROI-only. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for VBM whole-brain comparisons of PTSD vs trauma-exposed controls.

The study does not perform voxel-based morphometry (VBM). Structural analyses used SIENAX for global tissue volumes and FSL FIRST for subcortical segmentation (region-based volumetry), along with ADC measures and PET; no whole-brain voxel-wise VBM results or coordinate-based between-group contrasts are reported. Although it includes an adult PTSD group and trauma-unexposed healthy controls, it fails the required inclusion criterion of reporting VBM-based whole-brain comparisons, so it must be excluded.

Although the study includes an adult PTSD group and a trauma-exposed resilient control group (meets sample criteria), and reports that total brain volume was measured using VBM, the paper does not report any whole-brain voxel-wise VBM results or coordinate-based between-group contrasts comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or unexposed controls. The main neuroimaging analyses reported are region-of-interest (ROI) cerebellar volume measurements rather than whole-brain VBM coordinates. Per the review’s inclusion criteria requiring at least one whole-brain VBM result (coordinate-based or equivalent) comparing PTSD vs controls, this study does not qualify and must be excluded.

The study uses voxel-based morphometry methods (SPM8 segmentation, modulation, smoothing of GM and WM) on structural MRI and reports whole-brain voxel-wise mass-univariate results and multivariate SVM results. Sample includes adults: 50 PTSD, 50 trauma-exposed without PTSD, and 40 trauma-unexposed healthy controls. The paper reports whole-brain VBM comparisons (PTSD vs healthy controls; PTSD vs trauma-exposed without PTSD; trauma-exposed without PTSD vs healthy controls) with FWE-corrected findings and supplementary tables of regions/coordinates (Tables S3–S9). Thus it meets all inclusion criteria (VBM measurement, appropriate groups, whole-brain voxel-based results). No exclusion criteria are met.

Although the study used voxel-based morphometry (VBM) as one imaging modality, it does not report whole-brain VBM between-group contrasts comparing individuals with PTSD to trauma-exposed without PTSD or trauma-unexposed healthy controls. The analysis is a multivariate multimodal canonical correlation (mCCA) linking continuous measures (presence of mTBI, CAPS-IV PTSD severity, BDI-II depression severity) to fused imaging modalities; reported results are canonical correlation maps and associations/correlations with symptom severity and mTBI status rather than coordinate-based whole-brain VBM comparisons of PTSD vs control groups. Therefore it fails the inclusion criterion requiring at least one whole-brain VBM between-group result comparing PTSD to a control group.

Although the study includes an adult PTSD group and a trauma-exposed control group and reports whole-brain vertex-wise findings, it does NOT use voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume/concentration. The imaging analysis is surface-based cortical thickness mapping using FreeSurfer (vertex-wise cortical thickness), not VBM. The inclusion criteria require VBM measures and coordinate-based VBM contrasts comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or unexposed controls. Because the neuroimaging modality/analysis does not meet the required VBM criterion, this study must be excluded.

This study does not report voxel-based morphometry (VBM) whole-brain results. It used FreeSurfer cortical thickness measures (region-of-interest analysis of the caudal anterior cingulate/dACC) rather than VBM of gray matter volume or concentration, and reported ROI correlations rather than coordinate-based whole-brain contrasts. Thus it violates the inclusion criteria requiring VBM methods and at least one whole-brain, coordinate-based between-group VBM contrast comparing PTSD to trauma-exposed or trauma-unexposed controls. Additionally, although it includes adult PTSD and healthy control groups, the ROI-only cortical-thickness approach places it within the exclusion criterion: “only region-of-interest (ROI) analyses with no whole-brain results.”

The study does not use voxel-based morphometry (VBM) of gray matter volume or concentration. It uses surface-based morphometry (FreeSurfer) to measure cortical thickness (SBM), and reports cortical thickness results rather than VBM coordinate-based whole-brain gray matter volume/concentration contrasts. Although the sample includes PTSD, trauma-exposed non-PTSD, and healthy control groups and performs whole-brain cortical-thickness analyses, it fails the primary inclusion criterion requiring VBM methods/reporting; thus it must be excluded.

execution_stats.search_query: ("Stress Disorders, Traumatic"[MeSH] OR PTSD[tiab] OR "post-traumatic stress"[tiab] OR "posttraumatic stress"[tiab]) AND ("voxel based morphometry"[tiab] OR VBM[tiab] OR morphometr*[tiab] OR volumetr*[tiab] OR "cortical thickness"[tiab] OR "brain volume"[tiab] OR "grey matter"[tiab] OR "gray matter"[tiab])
